name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 27 November 2014 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Freedom of the media and media pluralism are fundamental values of the European Union.  Turkey is a candidate country with which we are negotiating accession. However, our relations with candidate countries must be characterised by mutual honesty and openness.  Precisely because we take negotiations with Turkey seriously, it is our task to make it clear where progress is being made, but also where we fear that there are wrong things. Problems with freedom of the press and freedom of expression are nothing new in Turkey. We were astonished to note the raids against journalists and social media in the aftermath of the protest in Gezi Park.  Yesterday we saw another wave of raids against anti-government media and are concerned that this is a sign that the development against opposition media is a dangerous one and one that we are particularly observing. Ladies and gentlemen, this applies to all democratic constitutional states: criticism must be met with arguments, ideas and evidence, not with retaliation, intimidation and arrest of journalists. I have therefore asked my services to ask the Turkish embassy to clarify what is happening immediately, and I would like to say here – certainly on your behalf – that we will be watching with great care what is happening in Turkey.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The Environment, public health and food safety concerning the draft Council decision on the accession of the European Union to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (09412/2014 - C8-0042/2014 - 2013/0418(NLE)) Rapporteur: Pilar Ayuso (A8-0036/2014).

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: deputy rapporteur. - Madam Vice-President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to apologise on behalf of the rapporteur, Mrs Ayuso, who, for personal reasons, cannot be present here today, but who thanks you for the previous parliamentary work. As you all know, CITES, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, which entered into force in 1975, seeks to protect species through international trade controls. It encompasses some 35,000 species, which are regulated in three appendices depending on the degree of protection they need. Since the Commission presented its proposal, there have been two new accessions to CITES, which currently has 180 parties, including all member states of the European Union. The European Union had so far observer status in CITES, as only Member States could be parties. However, this situation changed in November 2013, with the entry into force of the "Gaborone Amendment", which allows regional economic integration organizations made up of States to become parties to the Convention. The request for approval sent to Parliament by the Council bases its draft Decision on a single Article of the Treaty, Article 192 on the environment, where while the Commission had based its initial proposal on Articles 192 and 207 on the common commercial policy. The opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs of this house considered that, in this case, the double legal basis proposed by the European Commission is appropriate. However, since Parliament has to adopt a recommendation concerning only the accession of the European Union to CITES, and has not been called upon to adopt a position on the legal basis, we have merely, in this context and only for the sake of legal clarity, merely mentioned the issue of the double legal basis in view. In our view, the European Union's accession to CITES is a logical and necessary step towards ensuring the Full Capacity of the European Union to follow its environmental policy objectives. Ms Ayuso says it is important to note that the rights and obligations of the Member States under the Convention will not be affected by this accession. In practice, the internal decision-making process will not be influenced, but will streamline the practices that are currently in place. For all the above, Mrs Ayuso asks me to convey to you that she believes that we should vote in favour of the European Union's accession to CITES.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, Commissioner Vella regrets that he is not able to be in Strasbourg today. He is in Brussels at the Fisheries Council, but he has asked me to present the views of the Commission on this file to you.  I would like, first of all, to thank Ms Ayuso and Ms Herranz García for their excellent and efficient work on this particular file. When presenting these political guidelines to Parliament in July, President Juncker made clear that one of the aims of the new Commission is to reinforce the EU as a strong global actor. The EU accession to the CITES Convention is to be seen in this context. The CITES Convention aims to make international trade in wildlife species sustainable. It is a very operational and efficient instrument that regulates millions of cross-border movements of animals, plants and commodities derived from them, such as timber, leather goods, medicines, cosmetics and food products. In total, we are talking about 35 000 species that are covered by CITES. This wide scope, combined with the legally binding nature of its decisions and its robust compliance mechanism, makes the CITES Convention a critical tool to address the overexploitation of natural resources, which is one of the biggest threats to biodiversity today. The CITES Convention stands at the crossroads of environment, trade and development. These are all areas in which the EU is a leading actor on the international scene. These are also areas in which the EU has strong legislation and policies. The EU’s accession to the Convention will reflect its leading role, and it will increase the EU’s visibility and accountability. The situation will be similar to the other organisations such as the WTO, the FAO or the Convention on Biological Diversity, of which the EU has been a full member for many years. In operational terms, the way we prepare for CITES meetings will not change much after the EU accession, as there is a well-established practice to agree on common EU positions before each meeting. However, the EU will gain visibility at the CITES meetings, as EU positions will be expressed by the EU on matters of EU competence. The EU will also be able to participate fully in the various bodies set up under the Convention and contribute to its annual budget.  This accession comes at a particularly important time. CITES has recently engaged much more in regulating international trade in marine and timber species. These are very valuable commodities traded in large amounts. The EU has pushed for these, and our accession to CITES will allow us to increase our investment further to ensure that the international timber and fish trades are legal and sustainable. CITES is also at the forefront of the fight against wildlife trafficking, a problem which I know is important to this Parliament. The current dramatic surge in wildlife trafficking calls for a strong response from the international community. At its last meeting in July, the CITES Standing Committee adopted very concrete measures targeting the countries most involved in wildlife trafficking, particularly in ivory, rhino horns and rosewood. These measures need to be implemented within strict deadlines, and failure to do so could result in the adoption of trade sanctions. Increasingly, CITES is also engaging in close cooperation with international organisations like the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, and Interpol, which also specialise in combating organised crime. The EU must play its role in these global efforts, and the accession to CITES is a very concrete step towards facilitating this. To conclude, I would stress that the EU’s accession to CITES will reinforce both the EU as a global player and CITES as an essential multilateral instrument for sustainable development. The Commission is aware of the interest of Parliament in these matters, and we count on your support in finally making it possible for the EU to become a full party to CITES.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, we can first thank Ms. Ayuzo and Ms. Garcia for doing an excellent job, and I can tell Mr. Commissioner on behalf of the European People's Party that you can count on our support, as I think this is a very important move given that the convention aims to establish worldwide control over the trade in endangered species of wild animals and plants. We know that since 1984 the European Union has been implementing the CITES Convention, but as we know, it could not sign it since only member states could. That is why it is very important that today, i.e. tomorrow, when we vote, the European Parliament adopts a recommendation on access to CITES, because as you said yourself, in November 2013 it was possible for the Union to join and be a full member.  Three aspects are important: both development, and international trade and environmental protection. And so far we have behaved in accordance with these provisions of this Convention, but then we referred to the provisions of the founding treaty of the European Union and that chapter that dealt with environmental protection.  In order to effectively implement this convention, I consider that continuous cooperation between all authorities is needed: customs, police, border, veterinary inspections, nature protection inspections. The annual value of international wildlife trade is estimated at billions of US dollars, and is classified on the illicit market by annual earnings for narcotics, arms and human trafficking.  Therefore, more than 35 000 species are being survived and therefore it is good that this document has come to the European Parliament, that through the convention we protect endangered species by prohibiting or making international trade in these species much more difficult by a specific permission system.  Endangered species of wild animals and plants whose trade is controlled are classified in three additions to the convention. In any case, once again on behalf of the European People's Party, we support the European Union becoming a global player in this part and strengthening cites' role.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I too would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Ayuso, for her work and to say to the Commissioner that she can also count on our group on this issue. As has already been said, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora provides a number of guarantees, so that international trade in specimens of flora and fauna does not threaten their survival. CITES protects more than 35 000 species and includes 178 countries, including all the Member States of the European Union. The EU can now finally be a contracting party and not just an observer. It is therefore a due act. This is due because the competences to implement the Convention fall, first and for all, on the European Union: it is a necessary step to make the protection of biodiversity and endangered species more effective. The protection, protection and improvement of the quality of the environment are the Union's priorities, according to the Treaties, together with the careful and rational use of natural resources and the international promotion of measures to solve environmental problems. In addition, the EU shall take measures for the proper functioning of the internal market and for the customs union, a common commercial policy. International trade at the expense of endangered species – think of the extermination of elephants and rhinos for tusks and horns, the indiscriminate hunting of fur animals and big cats, the slaughter of rare trees for their timber – generates an annual turnover of 200 billion dollars. This barbarity impoverishes the Earth, to enrich some criminal organizations and often fuel wars and terrorism.  That is why we can only welcome the European Union's direct intervention in CITES and its accession, as planned, in the proposal for a Council decision, and we can also thank all the law enforcement agencies that monitor compliance with these rules.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The CITES Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Animals and Plants is now more than 40 years old, but more needed than ever. CITES – as has already been said – offers protection to no less than 35 000 species of animals and plants. If, for example, the African black rhino was provisionally saved from extinction, this convention is one of the things that is being done. The World Wildlife Fund estimates the value of the illegal trade in endangered species and derivatives at USD 19 billion alone. This is the fourth largest illegal trade after drugs, counterfeiting and human trafficking. And the profits often finance war and terrorism. The CITES Treaty regulates international trade so that it can be done in a sustainable way with an eye for human needs and for the economy. Indeed, 180 countries have already joined CITES, including all 28 EU Member States.  Today we are talking about the European Union's accession to the agreement. As shadow rapporteur for the ECR Group, I can confirm that we support this accession. It promotes legal transparency about the precise role of the European Union and its effectiveness. By the way, this is not unique. The EU has previously joined other international environmental conventions such as the Bonn Convention, the Carthagena Protocol and the Nagoya Protocol. I would like to stress that there are clearly defined responsibilities between the EU and the Member States and that the EU's accession to CITES has no influence on the distribution of powers between the EU and the Member States, nor on the way in which a common EU position is determined.  The only tricky issue is whether this dossier should have a double legal basis (environment and trade). But this discussion will not stand in the way of our approval tomorrow in plenary.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I must say I am relieved that finally the EU can become a party to the CITES Conference. I witnessed myself how important this is a few years ago when I was part of Parliament’s delegation to the CITES Conference in Doha. We did not speak with one voice, we were not very united, we were more occupied by our internal negotiations as EU Member States and then we made a strong position at the Conference itself, so I am very relieved that we have finally become a party to CITES. Another thing I would like to address here – and the Commissioner has already mentioned it, as have many of my colleagues – is the importance of the fight against wildlife trafficking. That is something that should be done with CITES but of course, and the Commission knows this, this is something that should also be done much more strongly within the EU. I therefore hope that Commissioner Moedas can give the message not only to his colleague responsible for the environment but also to his colleagues higher up the hierarchy in the Commission that we really need an EU action plan against wildlife trafficking, and the sooner the better.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I welcome today’s recommendation for the EU’s accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Plants and Animals. The European Union cannot be found wanting in its actions, and it cannot allow species like the African elephant and rhino to be consigned to the history books. 22 000 African elephants were killed for their ivory in 2012 alone. 95% of the world’s rhinos have been wiped out in the last forty years, and let us also not forget all the other less well-known species that are illegally traded on a daily basis. The impact that losses like these have on ecosystems is catastrophic.  The EU and Member States must, of course, comply with obligations under this Convention, but it is one thing to ban or limit trade and it is another to effectively enforce it. One cannot ignore the fact that the vast majority of this illegal trade is carried out in the developing world in conflict zones. The EU, of course, should support these countries where they lack equipment and funds for enforcement, but we must also look at the bigger picture. If annual turnover for the illegal trade is estimated to be USD 19 billion – making it the fourth-largest illegal trade in the world – the extreme poverty of many African communities lends itself to this trade. When the tusks of a single adult elephant are worth more than ten times the average annual income in many of these countries, is it any wonder that impoverished people resort to wildlife trade?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Green Group and I warmly welcome and support the accession of the EU to CITES, which is one of the world’s most powerful tools for biodiversity conservation. It is clearly a necessary and desirable development. However, as I see it, this step is only a drop in the bucket. Let me remind you that, despite the EU’s commitment to halve the loss of biodiversity in the EU by 2020 and to restore biodiversity wherever possible, in the longer term – as well as in the long-term vision for biodiversity for 2050 – natural capital and ecosystems services are being continuously depleted. This will have profound consequences for our wellbeing. As stated by the Commission itself, over half of the habitats and species covered by the EU Habitats Directive are considered to be in an unfavourable conservation status. There is evidence that the status of many ecosystems is reaching, or has already reached, the point of no return. It is estimated that each year we lose 3% of our GDP due to the loss of biodiversity. Besides undermining the economy through diversity loss, changes in habitats and ecosystems also erode social cohesion in and outside the EU. Thus we must step up efforts in Europe to achieve our biodiversity targets. We must ensure that none of the policies of the EU or of its Member States have harmful impacts on biodiversity. We must reinvest in natural capital, construct green infrastructure and ensure that all spending under the EU budget is supportive of halting the loss of biodiversity. I therefore urge the European Commission and all European decision-makers to set their priorities and structure their work mindful of the biodiversity targets, and not to compromise biodiversity, as it is crucial to sustaining the ecological systems and the services we all depend on.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the entry of the European Union as a member of the Washington Convention can only be agreed, just as the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy expressed its opinion on this with virtually unanimous opinion. CITES has been ratified by 180 countries around the world and is probably one of the most effective regulations that has contributed to the protection of protected species. The opportunity for the European Union to enter the Convention must, however, be an incentive to do even more, much more in the context of the illegal trafficking of wild species. In 2011, the value of the European market for products belonging to species listed in the Washington Convention was estimated at almost EUR 500 million. Europol notes that, in recent years, the level of criminal activity increasingly organised and present in the field of the illegal trade in wild species is increasing. The European Union is increasingly a consumer but also a producer of illegally acquired natural resources to be marketed. There are over 37 000 registrations in the European database of abductions of species included in CITES, a clear sign of a huge illegal market. An example of this is the massive illegal import of meat from Africa, the so-called 'bush meat' which, in the countries of origin, is an important food resource, whereas here it is just a treat and the ostentation of a welfare state: we are talking about about 270 tonnes of illegally imported meat, only through Paris airport. I therefore welcome the entry of the Eu ropean Union as a member of CITES, but we are also taking other initiatives, such as strengthening the rules, improving data collection and tightening penalties for offenders.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: A proposal for a Council decision to include the European Union in the Convention on International Trade in Species of Wild Fauna and Flora will come for adoption in the coming days. The need to vote in favour of the proposal becomes obvious if one realises that, since the early 1970s, people, for commercial gain reasons, have been occupied by an inexplicable mania for the destruction of many species of plants and animals which are at risk of extinction from the planet. It is estimated that by 2020 around 10 million of these plants and animals will have disappeared. If we take into account the loss of animals mainly as a result of human destruction of forests, pastures, coral reefs and the pollution of the seas, which comes back from humans, then this number of animals is reaching the limits of tragedy. The European Union is therefore facing a very important challenge, to which it must respond successfully. It starts with the best of intentions. But it is asked: Will it succeed in limiting the uncontrolled action of the legal and illegal traders of these species so far? Will it be able to control the trade in these species over the internet? Finally, will it be able to ensure international cooperation in order to promote, at international level, measures which, on the one hand, protect these species and, on the other hand, guarantee the protection of the environment, so that human life can also be made better but at the same time better living conditions can be guaranteed? I hope that we will succeed in this endeavour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam Vice-President, as a person who advocates the protection of the legal order but also for the protection of endangered wild, plant and animal species, I call on the competent authorities of the European Union to do their um, so that the European Union accedes to the CITES Convention.  The Convention today protects over 35 000 different plant and animal species, some 1,000 of them, or 3% are endangered and face the risk of extinction precisely because of trade. The Republic of Croatia has been a party to the convention since 2000, has achieved very notable results in the fight against trade in exotic species, and this year a very large seizure of exotic plants and animals was carried out.  Every year, tens of millions of specimens of plants and animals enter the international wildlife trade, and the value of that trade is over $10 billion a year. Extremely rare and critically endangered Madagascar turtles on the illegal market fetch a price of up to 25 000 euros per piece, and rare Lear parrots from Brazil can cost a dizzying 90,000 euros per copy. A kilogram of rhino horn on the black market costs more than a kilogram of gold. Ivory is still a luxury product and a status symbol, so the price of raw ivory is up to 5 000 euros per kilogram, while carved items cost a lot more.  The demand for these products has resulted in mass poaching of these species, so in 2012 22,000 elephants were killed in poaching, and over 1,000 rhinos have died in south Africa's territory alone due to poaching. Unfortunately, people are also suffering in the whole process, so globally, 56 rangers have lost their lives on official duty in the past 12 months, 29 of whom have been killed by poachers.  I therefore call once again on the competent authorities of the European Union as a person in favour of the protection of the legal order for the European Union to join cites convention.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: I also asked for the floor to highlight the importance of the "Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora" and the new statute of the European Union. I have been closely following the implementation and I can attest to how progressively this instrument is increasingly efficient. In my country, Portugal, and more specifically, the Azores, the region from which I come from, the application of this instrument has given the authorities the legitimacy to act and, among citizens, reinforced awareness of the importance of safeguarding wild species. Internationally, there is still a lot of illegal and unregulated activity. Thus, it is necessary to combat, by all means, the use of wild fauna and flora in the name of voodoo pseudoscience, the collection of living organisms, applications in jewelry, furniture, decorative objects, including clothing. Species such as gorillas, rhinos, turtles, black corals, remain in danger. Increasing global commercial transport and selling on the internet must be increasingly effective in monitoring and regulation. The European Union must be intolerant of trade in endangered species. I therefore welcome the new statute of the European Commission and hope that it will be an opportunity for greater proactivity.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Madam President, I welcome the accession of the EU to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. This will enable the EU to take a committed position and play a full role in the Convention. Article 191 allows the EU to promote measures at international level to deal with worldwide environmental problems; and what could be more apposite than endangered species? All Member States are signed up to CITES already, so why the necessity for this accession? What does it add?  In my view this will give the EU a platform to move forward together at the Conference of the Parties, employing the power and influence of all 28 Member States together, and I hope that in the near future we will be able to use this influence to promote tougher enforcement of the licensing system. Barely a week goes by when we do not see some new seizure of goods or medicines fashioned from endangered species, from tigers’ bones to rhino horn. Last week we saw in Hong Kong just such a thing. I would like to see this as just the very beginning of the EU’s new approach to CITES. The burden of the questions should be moved not from what we can trade, but why we should trade at all, and the EU could be at the forefront of that discussion.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Madam President, we must all cheer about the change in the EU’s status in CITES from observer to full member. As a full member the EU will speak with and vote with one voice in CITES negotiations. We will also be responsible for implementing and enforcing the Convention and will participate fully in CITES projects. This marks an important step in the protection of highly endangered species around the world. More than ever, international coordinated action is needed to end illegal wildlife trade, stop poaching and the increasing rate of biodiversity loss. Over 20 000 elephants were killed by poachers last year; a record 668 rhinos in South Africa alone were killed for their horns just to make trinkets and medicines that do not work. Unless we act now these species and many others will become extinct. But the trade in living wild animals is also thriving. At this very moment the Zimbabwe government is profiteering from baby elephants removed from their herds to be sold to zoos in China and the UAE. These animals face extreme stress, poor conditions and are at a high risk of early death. All parties to CITES must act decisively and quickly to prevent animals being traded as commodities. They deserve our protection. We can and must develop an action plan, working closely with countries such as China. The EU can be a global leader in the fight against this serious and most profitable crime as a full member of CITES. We have a duty to raise awareness, impose stricter controls and introduce dissuasive penalties for those who profit from illegal wildlife trade.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! According to a WWF report, the number of animals living worldwide has halved in the last 40 years. It is equally dramatic with other animal species, and more than 70% of all plant species are already considered threatened. In addition to natural extinction, the main causes are anthropogenic causes: climate change, rainforest deforestation, marine pollution, mass animal husbandry, the use of pesticides and insecticides, but also trade in wild animals and wild plants, which is estimated at several billion euros per year, for example, 1.5 million wild birds and around 440 000 tonnes of medicinal plants are traded each year. We have a moral obligation to stop this madness before tens of thousands of animal and plant species leave the world stage forever every year. We can stop species extinction by combating climate change, by taking action against rainforest destruction, by reducing livestock farming, but also by restricting trade. One effective option would be to increase the EU's influence in the forthcoming CITES negotiations through full EU membership. The truth is often that the protection of endangered species falls victim to national economic interests. We must prevent this, the EU must prevent it. I would like to conclude by saying that we need this earth, but the earth does not need us.

name: Julia REID
text: Madam President, if it is large, grey, has a trunk and looks like an elephant, then that is exactly what it is: an elephant. CITES was created for signing by sovereign states. However, it is now to be signed by the European Union. Yet again the European Union behaves like a sovereign state. Like the elephant, if it has ever more characteristics of a sovereign state, then it is obvious to all that this is exactly what the EU is becoming. There are those, especially in the UK, who are in denial about this fact: that the European Union, as a direct, inevitable consequence of the commitment to ever-closer union, and as set out in successive treaties, is taking over the sovereignty of Member States. This recommendation is proof positive of what UKIP has long been saying (but LIB/LAB/CON denies): that the EU is ever more sovereign. The usual weasel words are in the report. It will enable the Commission to lead negotiations and be a catalyst. Signing CITES may be very sensible for sovereign states, but the EU signing CITES represents yet another EU power-grab. The EU acquires the one vote, counting as 28 votes, and my country along with 27 others lose yet another freedom to decide for themselves. Truly there is an elephant in the room. It is called the European Union.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: I believe that we all feel compliered with for the protection of nature throughout the world, which is why we support this convention, to which the European Union is to accede as a whole. The common European market is one of our greatest advantages, so it is essential to act together in this area, because this convention on international trade concerns the common European market and our common European approach. As is known, the history of the Convention dates back to July 1, 1975 and includes more than 35,000 species of endangered animals and plants. Let me point out that from Slovak species they are such rare species as king eagle, hunting falcon or river otter. The accession of the European Union to CITES ensures greater transparency of the Union's legal position within CITES vis-à-vis third parties to the Convention. Rather, the current observer status represented a disadvantage and did not allow the Union to fully implement its environmental policy objectives. The Union will contribute 2.5% of the total amount of the CITES Trust Fund each year, which is around EUR 115 000 next year, and member states' contributions will be reduced accordingly. This is further proof of the advantage of the common European procedure. Accession will enable the Commission to take a unified position on behalf of the Union, thereby improving the EU's position in controlling international trade. I believe that our agreement – by the European Parliament – to the Accession of the Union to this Convention on International Trade will not only contribute to a more effective protection of endangered species of wild fauna and flora, but will also speed up the decision-making process and, in particular, align the necessary common European action.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: International trade in wild fauna and flora severely restricts the survival and development of animal species and plant specimens around the world. In the end, many of you have already mentioned this. CITES thus provides protection for over 35 000 species and makes a significant contribution to the control of illegal international trade in this area. At present, the Member States are members of the Convention, but we believe that the time has come for the status to change and for the European Union, which currently only acts as an observer, to be given new powers. Accession to CITES will not affect the rights and obligations of the Member States, because the European Union will only vote on those issues that relate to the acquis, and individual Member States will continue to vote on all other matters. However, the accession of the European Union to CITES will ensure greater transparency of the legal environment and the position of the European Union vis-à-vis third parties to the Convention.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, CITES is an important international convention which, to the extent that it is effectively implemented, can protect wildlife. There are thousands of species protected by CITES and through this convention smuggling and the various circuits enriched by the trade in endangered animals can be hit. The role of the Convention is therefore positive and I believe that the European Union should accede to this Convention. However, the way in which the European Union will accede must fully respect the competences of the Member States within the scope of the Treaty. At the same time, this should also apply in the future, and the Commission should not attempt in an indirect way to extend, as it usually does, the competences of the European Union to the detriment of the competences of the Member States. For this reason, the Commission must be under constant scrutiny and accountability before the European Parliament. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, sir, you have just declared that you are in favour of the European Union's accession to the Convention on International Wildlife Trade, but at the same time you want to preserve the competence of States. I see this as a contradiction: if the European Union adheres to this convention, States will necessarily lose a new part of their sovereignty, as one of the previous speakers has said. What do you think?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: "blue card" answer. – I wanted to point out to my colleague that the competences of the European Union are specific and are defined, as are the competences of the Member States. That is why I have pointed out that it is possible to join the European Union, which will exercise its competences within their scope, as specifically defined by the Treaty on European Union. That is why I stressed at the same time that the Commission cannot and must not indirectly try to extend its powers to other areas to the detriment of the Member States. What I have said does not conflict but is based on the Treaty of Lisbon as regards the safeguarding of the competences of the Member States.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, during the minute of speaking time that is allotted to me, I will limit myself to two observations. Firstly, Commissioner, I fully agree with your view that the European Union must now fully assume its responsibilities in global governance, in an area which corresponds to a real issue of civilisation. We can see that the European Union's leading role in the conferences of the parties on climate has given them a new impetus. I hope that this impetus will be given in the fight against the wildlife trade. Secondly, this question refers us to the broader debate, perhaps philosophical, for that matter, about the relationship of our species with the rest of the world of life. We are still this somewhat curious species which, in order to satisfy the often futile needs of consumers around the world - and often European consumers - comes to commit mass crimes. We need to take action. Today we are experiencing the sixth wave of species extinction since the beginning of this world.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the European Union's accession to the International Convention against Trafficking in Endangered Species. This is an important decision, since, despite the commitment of the Member States, the European Union is still today one of the three privileged destination for specimens and products of endangered species, together with the United States and Japan. There are, however, some positive projects, also implemented by individual Member States, such as the purchase of vigogna wool, for example, which have demonstrated the possibility of reconciling the protection of vulnerable species with the need to support indigenous peoples, who are therefore involved in protection programmes. There is also a need to improve intelligence activities in both the countries of origin and destination, including through the wider dissemination of common databases, such as the EU-TWIX system. We also expect the European Union to make an active contribution to a special coordination programme for interpol's 'Infraterra' initiative, so that the nine largest wanted persons for environmental crimes, including the main culprits of the clandestine market in vulnerable species, are arrested as soon as possible.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by joining the Convention on International Trade in Species of Wild Fauna and Flora threatened with extension, the EU is finally equipding itself with an important instrument to protect biodiversity. The EU's participation as a legal entity in this system of species protection can only underline the EU's important position and responsibility in promoting environmental sustainability. More than 35 000 species are covered by the provisions of the Convention. We now finally have an even more certain legal framework, also for the benefit of the safety of European citizens, which regulates the introduction and import of protected flora and fauna. We are therefore preparing to ratify an instrument that will strengthen the coherence and negotiating weight of the European Union in the international arena, in particular consistency with the Treaty of Lisbon in giving the European Commission full competence in the field of trade and the environment. Another step towards a stronger EU role in the world for sustainability and environmental responsibility.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Madam President, it is a sad reflection on mankind that we can put a man on the moon, but we are not capable of keeping some of our most valuable animals alive on earth. We give the highest financial value to those commodities that are scarcest on earth, but sadly that logic applies to animals as well – even to the point that the rarer a species becomes, the more sought-after and the more valuable it or its body parts become.  It is now the stroke of midnight for a number of the world’s most endangered species. However, there is still time – but only if mankind can work together to get a message to all cultures on earth that we cannot go on like this, to outlaw the immoral trade in animal products from rare species, and to urge all authorities to join in enforcement. I commend CITES and I welcome the accession of the EU.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Five thousand animal species and twenty-eight thousand plant species are protected by the Convention. Nine hundred at risk of imminent disappearance. We need mechanisms to prevent their extinction, either by over-exploitation or by illegal trade, which increasingly affects a greater number of species.  Fifty thousand primates, four million birds, three hundred and fifty million tropical fish circulate illegally every year. Between 60 and 80% die on the trip. The market is clearly defined: supply comes from tropical countries, demand is concentrated in rich countries, consumers are looking for rare specimens and it is the pharmaceutical industry that buys species of spiders and poisonous snakes for experiments and new medicines. The European Union is the main consumer of these exotic animals. It is the world's first importer of reptile skins, parrots, good constrictors and pythons. He is the second importer of primates and felines. We also need, and I conclude, effective tools to prevent these exotic species from becoming brooms in the countries of destination.

name: Neena GILL
text: Madam President, I wholeheartedly welcome the prospect of EU accession to CITES, which has been overdue for decades. CITES clearly constitutes an area in which the EU has the potential to produce results which far outweigh the sum of actions taken by individual Member States. Issues relating to CITES have a crucial impact on EU policy in a great number of areas. Wildlife trafficking, for example, is not only unethical because of the harm it causes to animals, but is also depriving local communities of sustainable development opportunities, robbing countries of potential tax revenues, deterring investment, providing financing to terrorist groups and enabling the spread of diseases like Ebola. So I strongly believe that the EU should take a leadership role in CITES in putting a stop to the trafficking of tigers and all other endangered species; and I recall in the last Parliament, when I was here, the impact of the save-the-tiger conference and exhibitions which I held here.  But I have to say I am somewhat disappointed that the UK has the questionable honour of harbouring the fourth-highest number of online adverts for the illegal sale of protected wildlife. The onus is now on the UK and all other EU governments to secure the budgets needed for appointing wildlife cybercrime officers to national crime units.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Madam President, this convention, however imperfect, is a useful instrument as long as its objective, namely to protect endangered species, remains unchanged. For the time being, Member States are voting individually, under their own responsibility, on the projects presented within CITES. Of course, they conform to a common position defined by the Council, but they are legally free to vote in another direction. What will change with the accession of the European Union is that it will be granted the right to vote for all Member States at the conferences of the parties. Therefore, this transfer of the vote constitutes a transfer of sovereignty to which we are opposed in principle. But there's more to it than that! We do not have confidence in the ability of the European Union to resist lobbyists, because they will demand restrictions or, on the contrary, removal of restrictions on trade in a particular threatened species. In particular, there is concern that some species of fish consumed by humans will be included in the CITES register, which would pave the way for a ban on their fishing. At the moment, this is not the case because it is the regional fisheries management agencies that regulate the commercial fishery. But there have been calling for fish for human consumption to be included in CITES. The danger is that, under the influence of some lobbyists, the European Union prefers to ban the fishing of certain species outright, rather than to regulate this fishery. That is why we refuse to sign a blank cheque to the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's accession to CITES is of fundamental importance in ensuring the preservation of biodiversity. Although the European Union did not immediately accede to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, it has always undertook, as early as 1 January 1984, to apply it fully. The European Union's accession to CITES is therefore the evolution and maturation of a natural and logical process, which will finally enable the Union to be properly represented and to direct the work of the Convention and to play its role effectively. By hering to CITES, the Eu ropean Union will further strengthen its leadership in environmental, animal protection and environmental policy, ensuring that international trade in endangered specimens does not reduce its survival at INTERNATIONAL LEVEL. I believe that accession, which would allow the Commission to play an essential role in the negotiations at the conferences of the parties, would increase the coherence and unity of The European Union's action on CITES issues and lead to greater alignment of the positions of the Member States. I am therefore convinced that accession must be seen as a logical and necessary step for the EU to be fully able to pursue the objectives it has set itself within the framework of its environmental policy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, tragic is what happens to elephants in Africa and elsewhere, tragically what happens to rhinos. It's tragic what's happening to all these extremely interesting species on other continents.  But I also want to warn about the problems that exist in Europe, I want to warn about those problems that exist among the Member States of the European Union. It is known that those smuggling these rare species of plants, i.e. birds, animals, even olms, are often caught on the borders between the Republic of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina or Slovenia or Italy.  I would like to propose harsh, harsh, extremely severe penalties for those caught smuggling, especially if they are nationals of the Member States of the European Union.

name: József NAGY
text: I very much welcome the European Union's annexation of CITES, because I expect a united stance in the protection of endangered species and biodiversity throughout the European Union, which is our moral responsibility. We often think that these are only exotic species, but many of our rare native protected species are becoming prey to local and international gangs, often in very sophisticated ways, even on the pretext that animals come from legal holdings. Within the European Union, largely without border controls, it is simply impossible to maintain order without a joint effort. There must be a unified and interconnected system of registration, tracing the movement of individuals coming from trade and from breeding stations, the supervision of the activities of breeders must be linked in order to eliminate fraud. And what the EU will have much more effective options for in the future than the Member States, that is to monitor online trade, because through this trade is the greatest threat to endangered species.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: We generally agree with this decision to join the European Union in this Convention. Thousands of endangered animal and plant species are at stake, as has been said. My concern is the means that the European Union will put at the service of this important mission. Without means, without effective intervention on the ground, this adoption of CITES will not make much sense. In some cases, veterinary control services have been dismantled within the European Union which have played a decisive role in the control and eradication of many important diseases such as swine fever, tuberculosis, etc.  That is why I draw attention to the need to strengthen the means of combating illegal trafficking in these species, in particular the strengthening of border inspection posts, the improvement of the training of the veterinary body - within the framework of the Food and Veterinary Office - and, if possible, in collaboration with the European Federation of Veterinarians, and it is also important to give Member States the means to protect their exclusive economic zones.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, as you know, our rapporteur Ms Ayuso was unavailable to speak in the debate. She was replaced by Ms Herranz García who is not available at the moment to speak, so I thank everyone for their contributions. (End of catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, we are grateful to hear the strong support of Parliament for the upcoming EU accession to CITES. With the prospect of Parliament giving its consent to the Council decision tomorrow the EU should finally be able to become a party to CITES next year and be ready for the next meeting of the CITES Standing Committee in January 2016 and the Conference of the Parties later the same year. Thank you for your support. The EU voice will be stronger in an international arena. The input of Parliament to future debates on CITES matters is important, and we will of course continue working with you on those issues. On the specific question raised here today on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking, we have taken good note of the Parliament resolution on wildlife trafficking and the recent letter signed by 81 MEPs arguing in favour of an EU wildlife action plan. As Commissioner Vella has already indicated, the EU should be leading the fight against wildlife trafficking both domestically and internationally. He will thus be consulting a number of Commissioner colleagues concerned by these issues with a view to considering all appropriate steps for possible follow-up, also taking into account the results of the public consultation which the Commission launched on this issue.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 16 December 2014. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. Trade in protected species is still a reality and it is necessary to protect animals from commercial practices that may put them at risk. This is what CITES is for, a convention already ratified by many countries, but only recently can it be ratified by the European Union. As my colleague Marco Affronte said a moment ago, there is still much to be done to protect species and we in the Five Star Movement will certainly not fail in our contribution. I would like to point out that the Council, in its request for consent sent to Parliament, referred only to Article 192 of the Treaties, environmental protection, and not to Article 207, international trade. Since this is a convention regulating trade, I repeat, TRADE, in animal and plant species in order to protect them from practices that may endanger them, it is important that the legal basis relating to international trade is also taken into account, because CITES simultaneously pursues both objectives of legal and non-harmful trade and of animal protection. It is only by including all possible areas of application that the Convention will be even more effective.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – The European Union must retain environmental protection among its main objectives and I believe that its accession to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) will be beneficial. It will also enable cooperation with other non-EU countries to be strengthened to protect endangered species. We must not forget for a moment the great diversity of plants, animals and habitats that Europe has, in a fairly narrow territory compared to other continents. According to industry specialists, half of Europe's wetlands have been drained and nearly three quarters of the dunes in France, Italy and Spain have disappeared. The most valuable habitats for wildlife and fauna are protected by law, but many of them are in poor condition and need to be restored. On the other hand, almost half of europe's mammals and a third of reptiles, fish and birds are endangered. This is mainly due to the fact that their habitats are shrinking as urban areas develop and some of the land is allocated to infrastructure projects, such as roads. As such, we need to protect all these species, both for current and future generations.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The protection of flora and fauna is a long-term policy of great importance, as it is the guarantee of the preservation of the natural environment in which we live, and which constitutes a great global wealth. This commitment to biodiversity is a struggle that I am fighting with my French and European colleagues in this Parliament, where we are nevertheless proposed texts and projects that threaten flora and fauna, like genetically modified organisms, and which glorify free trade. The European Union therefore does not seem to agree with itself when it seeks to drape itself in conventions that give it good conscience. Moreover, for most of them, the Member States have already acceded to this Convention and the accession of the Union would be tantamount to denying the interpretations that nations produce of this Convention, as well as to establishing the illegitimate authority of European technocracy. Finally, this recommendation of varnish cannot receive my support since the greatest advance in this area would be the restriction of free trade and the strengthening of local policies carried out by free nations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on implementation of the Fuel Quality Directive (2014/2995 (RSP)).

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner Arias Cañete regrets that he is not able to be here today. I hope this long discussion on the calculation methods and reporting requirements pursuant to Article 7a of the Fuel Quality Directive can come to an end so that Member States can start to transpose these elements of the 2020 climate and energy package. We must now ensure that the Member States can put mitigation measures in place to achieve the 6 % greenhouse gas reduction target in fuels by 2020. The Council has reached a qualified majority on the Commission’s October proposal. However, I understand that some Members of this Parliament consider the proposal unambitious, claiming that it will not prevent unconventional sources of oil such as tar sands coming onto the EU market. The Commission would like to recall that the purpose of Article 7a of the Fuel Quality Directive is to reduce the carbon content of fuel used for road transport. The aim of the directive is not to discourage the use of any specific type of fuel but to ensure that appropriate mitigation measures are put in place to achieve the 6 % greenhouse gas reduction target by 2020. The Commission is convinced that the Fuel Quality Directive’s greenhouse gas reduction target can be implemented effectively both domestically and abroad through the proposal. The new Commission proposal agreed by the Council is thus a balanced and workable compromise as it delivers the objectives of the basic act while addressing key stakeholder concerns in an adequate manner. However, the Commission will be evaluating the experience with Article 7a of the Directive as part of its better regulation programme for the period after 2020. All options will be analysed to bring down greenhouse gas emissions from transport fuels in line with the overall target of achieving a reduction of at least 40 % by 2030. All stakeholders, including Parliament, will be invited to bring forward their views among others at the Conference to be organised in the course of 2015.

name: András GYÜRK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Thank you very much for the word. Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, my fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions from fuels is an important element of the European Union's efforts to combat climate change. The European Union, as a pioneer in this fight at international level, cannot afford not to achieve its objectives.  At the same time, we must achieve these objectives in the interests of industry. We need to create regulations that impose as little bureaucratic burden as possible on economic operators. We are both responsible for protecting our environment and for the competitiveness of the continent and for preserving jobs. In my opinion, in the Commission's proposal, these aspects are properly combined.  I would like to draw the attention of my fellow Members who wish to vote against the Commission's proposal in so that they risk five years of work even with the best of intentions. This is a compromise proposal, so it is far from perfect, but a consensus solution has been reached through lengthy negotiations, which will lead to the start of work on reducing emissions. For distributors to report greenhouse gas emission levels for the raw materials they actually use sounds good. Unfortunately, the practical implementation of this does not seem realistic. On the one hand, it is not possible to verify whether the producing countries provide the EU with credible data and, on the other hand, obtaining the necessary certificates would place a disproportionate administrative burden on industry.  Furthermore, this methodology may put market participants who have no intention of importing Canadian oil sands, for example, at a competitive disadvantage, but have limited opportunities for the purchase of raw materials. The average overall value is, in my opinion, a good tool for bridging these problems.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I therefore propose, on this basis, that we adopt the Commission's proposal. A possible rejection could also put the 6% emission reduction target at risk. Thank you very much for the floor, Madam President.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We had an interesting debate in the Committee on the Environment on the Fuel Quality Directive. It has just been said that we have realistic values here. If values are reduced by 40% from 2011 to 2014 – by 40%! – then you have to make it stupid. You have to think: what is the reason? Have any environmental aspects been added? No, I don't think so. I believe that it has something to do with negotiations on a free trade agreement. I can only say and warn against this: if this is to be done in the future in such a way that laws that have been put in place under the climate and energy package are so watered down and broken in the comitology procedure, then we can soon pack up, then we in the European Union will become a joke figure in the international negotiations. That is why we should either get together so that there is a compromise and the Commission is making another statement today. I think it is nice that you are here today, but I would have expected someone else – or two would have stood for the alternative, but good that you are there – with whom we are discussing. I would have liked the Commission to come here with a clear message about how we can get the cow off the ice. All that remains for us is to say yes or no. And the pendulum is swinging towards 'no', because we are providing the blueprint for future negotiations on free trade agreements for all international partners who want to negotiate something with the EU. Let's just lower the standards! You just have to lobby enough, then you get it. Politically, we have to say no, environmental policy, climate policy, we have to say no to it. And that is not how Parliament is to be deal with at the end of the day! It is a naughty thing to pull values through the grinder as much as it has been done here over the last three years. It's a naughty thing!

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Mr Groote says that we can only say no. Well, in actual fact this decision on the Fuel Quality Directive (FQD) is being considered under the regulatory procedure with scrutiny, as it relates to pre-Lisbon regulatory procedure and this has not been aligned. This means that the objection must be justified. It is not a question of saying yes or no. The objection must be justified on one of three grounds. The proposers of the objection have chosen ground number three, that it is incompatible with the aim and content of the basic Act. This suggests that the measure is inappropriate for accurate estimating and reporting of the volume, type, origin and lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions of the fuels supplied. Whilst for me also it does not go quite as far as some Members would like, the case for grounds under point 3 is not proven. I think there is much to recommend the Commission’s proposal. The proposal requires major fuel suppliers to disclose the trade names and volumes of the crude oils they import. This is a positive step and will provide a level of transparency to the public that does not currently exist in the EU. As trade names are generally associated with crude oil types, the tracking of this information will allow for a simpler updating of the EU fossil fuel mix’s carbon intensity in the future. Furthermore, with the Fuel Quality Directive currently not included in the Commission’s post-2020 Energy and Climate Framework, the adoption of this objection will only serve to undermine the credibility of the FQD by forcing additional institutional delay on a piece of legislation set to expire in six years. I think this would be a poor way forward and that the better compromise – and Mr Groote is looking for a compromise from the Commission – would be for Parliament to move forward with the Commission’s proposal in the spirit in which it has been offered, that is, as a way forward, and make sure that we get somewhere in the next several years, and do not just leave this lying in an interinstitutional wrangle.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it was this weekend that I returned from Lima where the climate summit took place, and I must say that I was impressed by the broadly shared determination to fight climate change. But the Lima outcome also made it clear that we still have a very difficult battle against climate change ahead of us. Let us face it: the world will emit more CO2 tomorrow than today, and more the day after tomorrow than tomorrow. For that reason, it is crucial that public policy pushes investments towards a low-carbon economy. As regards the Fuel Quality Directive, differentiation between different feedstocks is crucial, but the current implementing measure does not do this any more. So highly polluting Nigerian crude or tar sand oils from other parts of the world are treated equally with much cleaner feedstock oils. That is against the objectives of the Fuel Quality Directive, and for that reason I tabled – together with a few other groups – the objection.  I am, therefore, extremely disappointed by the statement from the Commission here today. I expected a much stronger commitment to the objectives of the Fuel Quality Directive. I really do not understand, after seeing your 2011 proposal, how you can defend a completely contradictory proposal after the Council rejected your first proposal. I really do not understand how you can defend both. It is absolutely clear that we have to steer investments, and we can only steer investments in the right direction if we encourage them in the right direction and discourage them from taking the wrong direction.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin with a question: how could the Council proposal coincide with the negotiations of the Free Trade Agreement with Canada? I ask this because its text responds exactly to what the oil lobby demanded: to open wide the oil doors of Canadian tar sands. They are well known that this fuel emits far more greenhouse gases than conventional oil refining — they know this because this is because it is written in the Commission's reports, in their reports. It is regrettable that these imports will not be penalized, but it is even more serious that they do not even try to control the increase in consumption of this harmful oil. As we have been denouncing, the Free Trade Agenda of the Council and the Commission, the agreements with Canada, with the United States, are conditional on eliminating laws that protect European citizens from environmental abuses, and this is a clear example of this. These setbacks aggravate the inconsistencies in the Union's energy efficiency policies. Even if these policies were implemented correctly, the imperatives of accumulation and profit lead the market to devour efficiency improvements: what is saved ends up being desustainable, environmentally and socially sustainable forms of production and consumption. Thus, for example, the intention to reduce emissions by betting on biofuels ends up becoming land grabbing and serious imbalances in the agricultural ecosystem and human food. We are not served patches; a sustainable alternative is possible.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I do not think that any of us here, any of the parties that filed an objection to this proposal, are against the Fuel Quality Directive. Let me be very clear, we are strong defenders of the Fuel Quality Directive. We think that, theoretically, this can be a very efficient tool. But that is the problem, we say theoretically, because with this proposal the Commission is deliberately weakening the proposal. It is weakening the effectiveness of the proposal, and I say this also to my colleague Julie Girling, who is saying you can only object on legal grounds.  If you read the impact assessment, with this proposal the Commission is deliberately taking away one of the options to achieve the 6 % reduction. Because of this proposal we can no longer differentiate between different feedstocks which is one of the three ways by which we can achieve the reduction. So this is literally taking away the efficiency of one of these measures, and that is what we are against. And this is very interesting, because if you read the impact assessment – and we are talking about better regulation, tomorrow the Commission will present a programme on better regulation – the most efficient proposal should be the proposal from 2011. That is in the emissions impact assessment. So why is the Commission not following its own impact assessment, not following its own proposal of 2011? Has the world changed? No, if you read the impact assessment all the values are the same as in 2011.  So we can only start to guess what happened, and indeed I come to the same conclusion as my colleague Matthias Groote. This is a consequence of the Canadian lobby. Probably all of you have been called or received e-mails from the Canadians saying that we really should support this measure. Why? Because now we can no longer differentiate between the fuel types and therefore the door will be open to tar sands. And that, of course, is the biggest problem: we are defending the Canadian lobby here. And let me say to the Canadians, who are probably listening, this is not against Canada. We just want to have differentiation between different fuel types. If the Canadians can show they can produce a clean fuel type, even cleaner than just normal oil, then they should also get the credit for that. So you need differentiation between fuel stocks. If you are more polluting it should be counted as such. If you are less polluting it should be counted as such. That is what we call better regulation, and that is not in the proposal. This is really going against the core of the Fuel Quality Directive. I agree very much with my colleague, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy. I was hoping that the Commission would get the point, that the Commission would realise that the Fuel Quality Directive and its methodology is something that is important and should be preserved. However, the Commission has only said we will review, we will organise a congress, and that is it. Sorry, we really want to hear more. How is the Commission going to make sure that after 2020 we will have a proposal that takes into account the differentiation between different fuel types so that the good ones are rewarded and the bad ones are not rewarded? That is what we are aiming for. And to my colleague from the EPP who said that this will throw away five years’ work, I say no, it is this proposal that is doing precisely that because officially the Commission is saying this methodology will end by 2020, and they are now just making an empty proposal. So if you really are concerned about the methodology then we should really fight for the proposal that was on the table in 2011 which does differentiate between different fuel types and which is even supported by ePure – not always my friends when they do their biofuel lobbying, but they also see that they are no longer being rewarded and are therefore saying that this time they agree to us objecting to the proposal. And I think that is also important for my Christian Democrat colleagues. So therefore we object, and unfortunately, Commission, you do not allow us to do anything other than to vote against this proposal, to object to this proposal, with pain in our hearts.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I endorse everything that mr Eickhout has said. I will add, some technical data, if possible, because not all the fossil sources from which fuels are derived are simply polluting for the environment and for health: some, they are even worse! They are devastating, for the environment and for health. I'm talking about tar sands and shale gas. A study recently published in the journal Atmosferic enviroment showed that air samples were taken in the large oil-processing area of tar sands and chemical processing in Canada where volatile organic chemical compounds recorded levels up to 6 000 times higher than normal levels. The leeward levels of 1,3-butadiene and benzene, which are very powerful carcinogens, were 322 times higher than those of the wind, and in the population living in those areas the medical records collected in just over ten years certified a considerable increase in leukemias and non-Hodhgkin lymphomas, especially as we approached the plumes of pollution. Nevertheless, the Commission's proposal for the calculation of emissions takes no account of tar sands and shale gas. Ladies and gentlemen, for the most part, you have been voted to defend the citizens and their own environment: but how can you still bear – for those who have done so – a Commission that does such things?

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against global warming and the reduction of greenhouse gases are among the major global ecological debates of the moment, as demonstrated by the Lima climate conference, which concluded this weekend. When it comes to going beyond the stage of incantations and good intentions, the debate becomes more complicated. If the subject were less serious, I would be tempted to say, with a touch of irony, that it becomes a Mexican, if not Peruvian, simplicity. In Lima , and with the prospect of a hypothetical global agreement at the end of 2015 in Paris, speakers discussed the sex of angels, with strong legal references, whether the solution lay in a binding international treaty or in a simple protocol, more flexible for developing countries. The Commission directive we are discussing today is one of the aspects of the European institutions' climate and energy policy. The Commission proposes five main axes for calculating the constraints that will be imposed on fuel producers to reduce the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions. It relies on highly technical considerations to do so. It is this method of calculation that is disputed by our excellent colleagues Gerbrandy and Eickhout. The two sides share at least one thing in common: both hide behind highly legal and mathematical considerations to conceal partisan motives, which take over the need for a real ecological policy. We blame the Commission's method of calculating for being a reflection of the well-understood interests of the North American oil industry. Canada's Minister of Natural Resources has publicly committed himself to European legislation that would be concerned with conventional supplies, reminding us of our international trade obligations. As for the authors of the objection made under Article 106 of the Regulation, they are looking for an excuse to distance themselves from this increasingly discredited and unpopular parliamentary majority, following its support for Jean-Claude Juncker. Yet they remain one of the pillars: the soup may not be organic, but it is good.  Our hope is that the ecological policy of our countries will follow criteria of general interest free, by definition, of the shopkeeper or mercantile spirit.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his This is not an efficient implementation of the Fuel Quality Directive, but a dangerous dilution of this very directive. I agree with the criticism that has been voiced many times here. What led you to make this change of direction? Only recently, you have carried out analyses that have clearly shown that the tar sands are much worse in their climate balance than conventional fuels of this kind. What has changed? Yes, it is probably not the situation, it is the same tar sands and not others, but probably your policy has changed. So that cannot be accepted here, because it is not clear why we should do so. We know that motor vehicle traffic has a high proportion, that we need to do something about this. In the 1990s, we have already seen dirty fuels coming onto the market, and that is precisely why this directive was made. We have seen this very well, that this is what we are faced with the new technologies – tar sands, shale gas – and we wanted to differentiate between the better fuels and the poorer fuels. It is not credible for our policy if we buckle now.  You have seen the lobby, you have heard it, you have felt it, but if we set a precedent here, then that will be a school. Then there are others who want something similar, and we can no longer make policies that serve climate protection, but only one that serves clientele interests. This Parliament is opposed to this. Nor do I believe that the burden on operators is so high. This differentiation can be made by simple means. In the age of the Internet, it's not hard to track that at all. So we have to reject that. Defend the beginnings! No precedent for watering down our policy!

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Madam President, if the Commission Work Programme is identical to the leaked paper we have already seen, then the headline of the third point includes a promise of – and I quote – ‘a Forward-Looking Climate Change Policy’. But to judge how forward-looking this issue is we should take a short look at history.  Almost eight years ago the EU decided, as a step towards the then upcoming Copenhagen Conference, on the climate and energy package. The Fuel Quality Directive is the only law from this package that has not been implemented. Considering the fact that 2020 is already almost round the corner and that we are approaching the Paris Conference next year, Europe needs a swift and strong implementation of this directive in order to be able to move forward towards the leading low-carbon society it intends to be. In order to be meaningful, a life-cycle approach has to be based on accounting that is accurate and possible. Proper accounting for life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions is therefore crucial to achieving this. Europe is already lagging behind its targets and investments are at a standstill. Developing policies and markets for highly greenhouse-gas-intensive fuels will not be the solution for Europe’s need.

name: Julia REID
text: Madam President, I am delighted to say that for once ordinary people are benefiting from an international development: oil and gas prices are falling. This is happening because friendly countries like the USA and Canada are opening up new fuel sources bringing down energy costs. One result is that we become less dependent upon unstable countries and unfriendly regimes. Another is that fuel costs come down for hard-pressed working people living through austerity. Good news for a new year but not of course if you are a Green. They want to do all they can to torpedo these developments. The Commission must not press for any agreement or sets of targets which will reduce or even reverse financial relief for hard-pressed taxpayers. It is after all the EU which created a currency full of structural flaws with disastrous consequences for the standard of living of millions. They must not compound their errors in the name of fighting climate change, especially as in recent years the climate has stubbornly refused to match the apocalyptic and dystopian forecasts.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Thank you very much for the opportunity! Dear Presidency, I agree with my fellow Members who, in this long, long debate, now more than five years old, say that the Commission's proposal is now somewhere else than the original objective, and I can honestly say that I, too, believe that during this time this compromise has been pushed in a particular direction because strong lobby groups have been able to push down relatively weak civilians.  However, I believe that the real solution is not necessarily within the framework of this directive, but that what we do not bring out from underground, but is produced here on the ground through sunlight – biofuels – can actually be the real solution. There is no dispute about minerals of different origins and grades brought out from underground. So thank you for your attention.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Madam President, it is so disappointing that the Commission has felt pressured to propose a weakened response to tar sands oil in the Fuel Quality Directive. The revised proposal ignores several recommendations of the European Parliament, including a differentiation between different fuel feedstocks. The Commission has also failed to recognise the results of its own impact assessments. As a result, highly polluting fuels, such as tar sands oil, will now be reported with the same emission values as conventional fuel stocks.
