And companies will be prevented from being able to report, even voluntarily, on real fuel emissions.  Rather than investing in cleaner fuels, the EU is opening up its market to dirty tar sands oil. This could mean nearly 7% of transport fuels in the EU are likely to come from Canadian tar sands by 2020. Mr Commissioner, please develop new proposals to extend the Fuel Quality Directive beyond 2020, taking into account the highly polluting nature of tar sands oil. If the EU is serious about leading the global fight against climate change, it must show it is serious about reducing emissions from the transport sector. We can only do that when we know what we are burning.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: I would like to draw Parliament's attention to one side of this directive, which is not about Canada at all, but concerns the issue of our European own fuel producers, who are also looking for you to obtain an environmentally friendly product from a wide range of fuel sources. One of them is the Estonian oil shale industry, where great efforts are being made to produce oil that is also eco-friendly from oil shale, including low sulphur fuels.  The Directive promotes this path of alternative search, and at the same time, this production in Estonia employs thousands of workers on estonia's eastern border, i.e. on the Russian border, and these workers are mainly members of the Russian minority. The proposal to reject the Commission directive means, for Estonia, that there is a fear of a double increase in unemployment in this highly sensitive region, certainly social tensions, and because it is a very sensitive region on the Russian border – and recalling Russia's rising aggression around the Baltic Sea – I very much hope that Parliament will take into account that this too will be an environmental problem when social tensions rise and the threat of military action increases.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Madam President, I might still be young and I might still be rather naive, but I do hope for a better tomorrow. That is why it hurts me so badly when we can see that the progress made by the Commission over the last four years has really been deteriorating. The proposals that we have on the table now are worse than they were three or four years ago, and the Commission is taking away the incentives for those who are not doing so well to do better. That is perhaps one of the hardest things to actually accept here, because we must believe that there is a possibility to do good. We are not prohibiting different kinds of fuels; but what we are saying in this House is that we need to have different regulations motivating those who are not doing well to actually do better. I am afraid that it is a sign of the new Commission. What we will probably hear tomorrow is that several items of great importance for the environment will be withdrawn. I do hope, Mr Commissioner, that I am wrong and that you will prove me wrong by doing better for the environment and for the future.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's proposal on communication methods and obligations under the Fuel Quality Directive has several shortcomings. It does not allow the differentiation between the intensity of greenhouse gases and different raw materials and, consequently, not even the communication of the real emissions of individual fuels. Under the proposed new calculation methods, Canadian tar sands, which represent high levels of pollution, are allocated, for example, an average greenhouse gas intensity value below their actual emission value and will therefore be favoured to be imported into the European market. In the light of these factors, I therefore believe that the objection that has been put forward to the proposal put forward by the European Commission, concerning the implementation of the fuel quality directive, is legitimate. However, I believe that, even in assessing the Commission's proposal, we must not forget the general context in which it fits in, namely that of energy security, which, following the recent events in Russia and Ukraine, cannot but be high on the European Union's agenda. I believe, however, that the Commission must continue to work towards the development of low-carbon fuels and innovative technologies that improve the environmental performance of fuel suppliers.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President! The point here is that we want to reduce the life cycle greenhouse gas intensity by 6% by 2020. This has already been said and made clear on several occasions. It has now also become clear to the Commission that the objectives have not been described ambitiously enough. Indeed, after a five-year process in the impact assessment, you said that the average greenhouse gas intensity per fuel is perhaps a real compromise, that you should report this, that you should record it. There are various things that need to be taken into account, but what can be said is that what you have said is now being rejected. On the one hand, it is true that Europe's competitiveness naturally plays a role, including dependence on imports, including, for example, the question of whether small and medium-sized enterprises can always withstand this. I am not concerned with big industry or Canada. I would like you to be able to give some answers from the Commission. The fact is – and I have now followed this whole debate – that it is clear that the ambitious objectives are not to be met now, not to be pursued. This is, of course, not in the interests of Europe.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: It is very important that life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions from all fuels are constrained and reduced and that the objectives of the 2020 Strategy are met. But what stemmed from this debate? The directive as such, which could be very good and beneficial, has become a directive where the Commission seems not to be working in favour, but rather against the effectiveness of this directive. This Directive must take into account realistic values. And it must also have realistic objectives. The intentions for the climate package should not be devalued. The Commission must come up with a fairly clear and real position, which will certainly receive support in this House. However, it must not lower standards because of political trade and under pressure from various lobbyists. This directive is important not only for us who are concerned with the environment and its protection, but it is also important for the generations that come after us. It is therefore our duty to insist that the Commission present us with a good directive.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, I expect the Commission to clearly propose what are the two key cornerstones of our work in the European Union, namely the fight against climate change, maintaining ambitions of 6% and of course what is on the other hand, a whole portfolio, which is a consumer protection issue. Here we are not talking about this element of consumer protection at all when we talk about chips, chocolate bars; we are talking about fuel used by all citizens of the European Union. Of course, in this context, I am maximally advocating a green economy and investment in a green economy.  However, the facts and problems that exist in one part of Europe, speaking specifically about Estonia, is something that the European Union needs to take into account and help such an economy. Because, of course, we can't put people out of work just because of some specific situations.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: Madam President, I think there is a vast amount of hypocrisy in this debate. I find it absolutely astonishing that 94% of the transport sector in the EU is dependent on fuel from oil, and yet the Commission is making arguments here about how this measure is not legally sound and is not appropriate. For one thing, we are putting a lot more investment into research and technology for alternative fuel development, and yet we fight over progressive measures such as this. It is absolutely ridiculous. Concerning recital 44 of the Fuel Quality Directive: how can it possibly be argued that strengthening what is on the table is not part of the objective of the directive, which is about ensuring respect for minimum levels of environmental protection in relation to fuel. We really need to get our act together, and I endorse what colleagues in the Socialist and Democrat Group – as well as many others – have said on this.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Madam President, I believe it is important to keep in mind that what we want to achieve with this is a reduction of CO2 emissions. Estonia has the specificity of having an oil and shale industry. It is a polluting industry. This is why investments have been made to restructure the sector and reduce its ecological footprint. Rejecting the proposal of the Commission would endanger the investments made and will likely lead to more pollution rather than less. The bigger picture of energy security in Europe and independence from Russia also needs to be looked at. Rejecting the proposal could have the impact of a shift of production and thus employment from north-east Estonia to Russia, and the risk of political instability would then be high. I am strongly in favour of a greener transport sector but I do not think that rejecting the Commission’s proposal this week will achieve this.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Thank you so much. Well, on the canvas of this debate, I wanted to raise two points very clearly. Firstly, it seems to me that we attach great importance only to the quality of fuels, and I think we should also pay attention to the fact that fuel supplies are certain. Therefore, it is not only quality that is important, but also the certainty of fuel supply. The Union should therefore pursue a common policy which, in addition to improving fuel quality, would also greatly enhance security of supply. Secondly, a very clear increase in funding for research and the deployment of new technologies is foreseen by 2020. I think that these measures would absolutely need to be increased and the means and preferences for research that would reduce gas emissions would have to be increased. I think these are two important goals.

name: João FERREIRA
text: The Commission's proposal on fuel quality is contradictory to its prolix rhetoric on combating climate change and the transition to a low-carbon economy. It is a friendly proposal for unconventional fuel exploration projects, while the relevant environmental issues that arise in this area underestimate their associated greenhouse gas emissions, which are known to be high.  We have said and repeated: the reality of the inexorable depletion of conventional and unconventional fossil fuel reserves and the challenges and upheaves necessarily associated with the transition require that the remaining fossil reserves on a global scale, as humanity's own imperative, be managed with immense wisdom, which means, first of all, that they are very sparingly. Neither this proposal nor the general action of the European Union are subsidiaries of this objective.  We recall the importance of the adoption of the so-called "Exhaustion Protocol", presented in Uppsala in 2002 and in Lisbon in 2005, aiming at a good and fair management of these resources and the mitigation of their lack.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I call for this directive to be completely changed at European level and for a ban on tar sands because of their destructive environmental impact. I also ask for help for the Region of Sardinia, where there is a private refinery that intends to use these tar sands. I call for the environment to be respected, because it is an island for environmental protection and for tourist prevalence.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this debate. I can just reiterate that with this proposal the objectives will be delivered and the target of a 6% greenhouse gas reduction by 2020 will be met. The objective of the Fuel Quality Directive is to reduce the carbon content of fuel used for road transport. The aim of the Fuel Quality Directive is not to discourage the use of any specific type of fuel but to ensure the appropriate accounting of greenhouse gas emissions. So I have taken due note of the range of opinions expressed and the concerns referring to the link with the trade agreement, the differentiation between fuel stocks and the extension of the Fuel Quality Directive beyond 2020, and I will duly convey these concerns to my fellow Commissioner Arias

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – The proposal on the table is not ideal, but at least we are moving forward after the dossier has been frozen for five years. The 6% target remains, that is the most important thing. By 2020, fuels in the EU should emit an average of 6% less CO2. The transparency that is coming is new and good. Importers must indicate where their raw fuel comes from. In any case, the Commission should report quarterly on the progress made and adjust if necessary.  Let us now move on to this compromise and not put our heels in the sand with no prospect of further results.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – The Fuel Quality Directive requires producers to reduce the greenhouse intensity of transport fuels by 6% by 2020. This greenhouse intensity also shows the polluting factor of the production of transport fuels. For example, the production of fuels from tar sands oil or shale oil is even more polluting than that from conventional oil. This is also reflected in the European Commission's own impact assessment from 2011.  The Commission now wants to treat all sources equally. It goes against its own impact assessment and against the European targets to reduce CO2 emissions. Without this differentiation, the European market will be quickly flooded with fuels from particularly polluting tar sands and shale oil. On the road to a trade agreement with Canada, the Commission has been wrapped up by canada's lobbying work, which wants to wear out its tar sands oil here. The alignment of fuels illustrates the progress we would make in reducing greenhouse gases in transport. An apparent decline could therefore in fact be an increase because of climate-damaging production.  The Commission is concerned with organised peasant fraud. It is particularly cynical, shortly after the Lima climate summit and in the run-up to the Paris summit in 2015, that Europe is throwing its leadership role in the fight against climate change into displeatry.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – The EU Directive on fuel quality is currently the most important EU tool aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport. Transport emissions depend on which raw materials the fuel is made from. In order to switch to oil forms with a lower carbon intensity in fuel production, reporting shall be based on the intensity value of each form of raw material used. In practice, the Commission's proposal that the raw material used should only be given an average over time for the various raw materials means that there will be no incentive to stop using highly polluting forms of oil, such as oil sands produced in Canada. In order to reduce transport emissions in the EU, every effort must be made to increase incentives for the production of cleaner and lower-carbon fuels.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on assessment of good repute of transport operators (2014/2978 (RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, ensuring effective and consistent enforcement of the EU rules in road transport is a priority for this Commission. We are fully aware that it is also of paramount importance for this Parliament. It is an obligation for drivers and operators to respect and apply these rules. Daily enforcement is primarily the responsibility of Member States. This proposal on common classification of serious infringements is there to help Member States to improve compliance and thereby increase safety on European roads. Its adoption would provide Member States with a common basis for assessing the good repute of transport operators in the event of infringements. The Commission has worked for over two years in order to come up with a balanced proposal on classification. This work should not be wasted. I know that some of you would wish to be even more ambitious and extend the scope to other infringements, in particular those of a social nature. Others evidently believe it goes too far. We all know that the glass can be seen as half-full or half-empty. But this proposal is clearly in line with the objectives and within the limits of the mandate this Parliament, as co-legislator, gave to the Commission. Accordingly, it would be difficult to explain to European citizens that the text on the table, which aims specifically to facilitate cross-border compliance with EU rules, may not be adopted. Road safety comes first for me; and whatever your decision is, I will continue to work with Parliament on this subject. But let me stress one more time that, among the negative consequences of possible rejection, we would face legal uncertainty for enforcers, unequal treatment of drivers and operators, as well as ineffective or even non-existent exchange of data on serious infringements between Member States for quite some time to come. Please keep this in mind when you vote. Please also note that we will always continue looking for new opportunities to keep our roads safe and working conditions fair. Finally, I would like to confirm again that the Commission is committed to continue the work on better enforcement of this acquis, and we hope that we can do so in close cooperation with you.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We may be doing something unusual today, but we are not doing anything undue. With the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has been given the right to review wherever the Commission is instructed to clarify or provide technical details and to lay down the specifications for the implementation of a directive wherever the Commission is instructed to clarify legislation. And that's what we did. We have checked what the Commission has worked out. Commissioner, I have almost been in tears at your speech, as you have impressively asked us what we have to do. I would have been pleased if you or your predecessor or the services you now are in chief had done what is laid down in the directive over the last two years. If you look at the delegated act, you see that it does not contribute to clarification, but everything remains vague and unclear. The task of this delegated act is to clarify and clearly specify when there has been a serious breach of the rules and not to put it back in the hands of the administrative authorities of the Member States. In other words, the political will of the legislator has not been carried out, but has been disregarded. In its delegated act, the Commission makes a distinction between minor, medium and serious infringements. This is generally to be welcomed. But if you take a closer look at the categorization, the classification – what is a light, a medium, a serious violation? – then everything remains vague again. There is no answer. But that is exactly what we have asked the Commission to do: to enshrine it in a delegated act. I would like to point out that, as far as road safety is concerned, we have a large number of laws and directives in force. When I look at what is in your delegated act, and when I look at what we have in the directive on the transport of dangerous goods, for example, things do not fit together. In other words, the Commission has also done something different here from what is formulated in other legislative texts. What I, and what we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, are fundamentally opposed to is that the transport industry and the many drivers who travel every day so that we in Europe can also experience the added value of the internal market are placed under general suspicion. We have a picture of an entrepreneur and an employee that is positive. You have a negative image. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats believes that this delegated act should be rejected. I hope that we will get a sufficient majority for this this week.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, Welcome, i believe that this is your first appearance here in the European Parliament – certainly not the last. Now I am well aware, Commissioner, that what is available does not necessarily come from your pen. I think it is fair to say that you have taken this from the last period from your predecessor, Mr Kallas. Now, of course, we know that, at a time when the European Union is trying to further liberalise freight transport, and in the end we are also trying to make everything more efficient through innovation and technical aids – and here I am with the previous speaker – the workers are falling a little by the wayside.  The European logistics industry, if you look at this, has an annual turnover of EUR 900 billion. That is a good thing, and it is a good place to do so. However, we must not forget those who contribute to this turnover. These are the workers who drive our goods, which we need every day, from A to B in the European Union on a daily basis. That is why I believe that this aspect must be added, and that has not been sufficiently done in the final stage of this proposal. If we look at the negative effects of so-called illegal cabotage – Commissioner, and I am convinced that you are actually with us on this point, as you have repeatedly said clearly in the hearings that you will not allow social dumping – we are at the moment in a situation in which health and safety at work and social standards are clearly being undermined. , and I believe that we simply have to stand up for these values. We must ensure that the categorisation as it is is supplemented is ultimately supplemented, as we have also told your service and its staff, that we ask that they be supplemented in order to clarify matters such as .B letterbox companies and social dumping. We will also reject this proposal, as it is on the table, and I hope that we will eventually be given a majority to reject it on Wednesday, in the hope – and I am in favour of this, by the way – that you will eventually take it up and take the opportunity to draw up a better legislative proposal in a relatively short time and to present it to the European Parliament. Then I believe that we can all work together on the content once again, and we can once again clearly develop the definitions. Then everyone knows what they are up to. However, the list is not sufficient at the moment, and please do not take that personally. But we will also reject this because it is not enough.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Hello Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am pleased that today we can participate together in this first debate with you on an important issue. A draft implementing regulation on the classification of serious infringements of EU rules, which could lead to a loss of good repute by the road haulier, will be voted on by the House on Wednesday. At the last meeting of the Committee on Transport, it was decided to refer this proposal back to the European Commission to supplement it. I agree with the past, and I hope that the European Parliament will confirm on Wednesday this decision of the Committee on Transport, which was already taken a few days ago. Why? Because the list submitted is not complete and does not exhaust both all categories of infringements leading to the loss of the good repute of transport operators, nor those that create a risk of serious injury to road users, as well as the social expectations of drivers. The European Commission's proposal is therefore not balanced, which consequently does not take into account the interests of either employers or employees. We expect a more rational approach, an in-depth analysis of the arguments of both parties and safeguarding their interests. The catalogue of infringements should in no way undermine the principle of subsidiarity or seek to eliminate road hauliers from the transport market.  Today we need an expert debate and discussion on infringements on the international road haulage market. We need to develop instruments that, on the one hand, would counteract illegal cabotage and, on the other hand, often take into account the rational arguments of drivers on social issues.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I would also like to welcome you to your first appearance here in plenary. This is indeed something historic for you, so you can say that. I liked the way in which you said that you want to work very closely with us in the future and that you are also saying that what is now available is appropriate to create legal clarity, to remove legal uncertainties and, at the same time, to be able to better punish all those who commit crimes in the transport sector. That is what should be done. You were not responsible for this yourself, as was still your predecessor – absolutely right. But two years of weighing up what can be done to better account for traffic offenders in international road transport. It has already been said that some people do not find it quite optimal how it went. I too do not have some details in the proposal. But overall, it can be said that this is a step in the right direction. We now have an opportunity – and this is necessary – to say more precisely how the rules are to be implemented now. This gives the Member States the assurance that they will be able to act accordingly. It was the case that, of course, some in the sector wrote to us – especially in Germany, there were many bus operators – who were afraid that the twelve-day rule could be repealed. That is not really the case. I have looked at it in more detail, that is not the case. On the contrary, it is even the case that this is to be maintained, and bus operators now know this too. As Mr Ferber said, we can reject what the Commission is proposing in this case, and that is always Parliament's right. However, I have the feeling, particularly in the case of what Mr Ferber said, that he contradicted himself in my terms, because, on the one hand, he said that various matters are not clearly regulated, with minor, medium and serious infringements. At the same time, he spoke of a general suspicion against all hauliers. In my opinion, this is contradictory. I think it is wrong to show Parliament's strength in this case, when it can be a matter of taking a step forward in punishing black sheep in cross-border traffic. That is why everyone should think carefully about how to do the vote.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Europe is not, and I hope will not, be the soil of cheap production. Our strengths in competition have always been based on maintaining professional skills, respecting working conditions and safe and environmentally tuned conditions. Safety and environmental legislation already has a long tradition and I would hope that these traditions can also be extended to social issues in working life and transport. Social dumping is neither an appropriate nor acceptable activity in Europe or anywhere in the world. In order to continue to improve both road safety and social conditions, we need to pay particular attention to these issues. Substandading working conditions, fake driving licences, illegal cabotage and underpayment are already among us. We have to act, we can't just wait! That is why the Commission will have a homework.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, on 30 January 2009, the European Commission adapted the 2006 directive. This directive was essential: it established rules on the control of legislation in the road sector, including driving, rest and rest times for European road drivers. The aim was to establish a common classification of social law violations in the road sector based on their seriousness, which should have put an end to the current disparities. Indeed, today an offence can be considered serious in one country and minor in another. The process of harmonizing the social and wage standards of road drivers has not progressed at the same rate as market liberalisation. Some companies use social dumping practices, which reduce their production costs by reducing labour costs at the same time. Road drivers are the first victims of this situation. Unfair competition practices run counter to their social rights and are pulling the whole of Europe down. It is high time to defend an upward harmonisation of the rights of European employees. What about today? Many states do not play the game, while the very purpose of a classification is to allow targeted control in companies where the level of compliance is too low. The Commission's proposal does not strengthen this harmonisation: on the contrary, it weakens it. So it is high time, really, to be ambitious today. We therefore ask you to include in this list of offences new criteria such as the violation of the rules on the certificates of road drivers, by adopting a real new legislation on the transport of hazardous materials, but also all the illegal practices that are too widespread, which result in an increase in social dumping in this sector at European level. In short, there is a real urgency: the proposal you are making to us is not up to scratch, we expect a lot from you.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the Commission's act on the good repute of hauliers is totally inadequate and insufficient. This category suffers serious damage as a result of these European rules which, on the one hand, promote the free movement of goods and persons but, on the other hand, forget to protect those who work in the internal market and are subject to obvious unfair competition. Let us consider the serious phenomena of illegal cabotage and social dumping which, for example, are destroying the entire sector in Italy. There are hauliers who are forced to compete with firms from outside which, thanks to more favourable national legislation, can charge cheaper prices, effectively causing the bankruptcy or relocation of so many of our small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore call on all of you, all of you, to undertake to urgently review the discipline in this area, bearing in mind that these workers are often forced to work unsustainable hours, which keep them away from their families for a long time.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work on Now you are doing a bit like me in this House today – I am also new to the Committee on Transport. We have already discussed this briefly in your interview. Now, of course, it is important to all of us that we achieve an improvement in road safety on Europe's roads. In this case, it is also, in principle, welcome to have a uniform Europe-wide regulation, something to combat scrap trucks. In Austria, we are particularly affected by this, because the proximity to eastern states is once again reflected on our roads. This now applies not only to road safety, as has already been mentioned on several occasions, but also to the workers who work in this area. I think the approach is a good one, namely that it is said that companies should set up the checkpoints – as we have here – and I think that makes sense. The idea of a traffic manager is also something that will have to prove itself in practice, but I think that also makes sense. For me, the question arises, as some Members have already said, how the classifications that are carried out there are then specifically explained, whether the subjects of the law then know exactly what to do there. I think that is doubtful. However, I was somewhat surprised today by my colleague from the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, who said that they would not agree to this. I think he will have his own particular reasons for not agreeing with that. Evil is the one who suspects evil in this case.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Mr President, I too would like to welcome the new Commissioner, Mrs Bulc, to the plenary of the European Parliament. Good luck and a pleasant collaboration in the coming years! We are discussing a list of serious violations in the transport sector today. We all know that transport is a vital part of the European economy and we would like to work with the Juncker Commission to improve the transport sector, make it fairer, ensure good competition, but also good social conditions for workers. Our group has come to the conclusion that this list is unclear and incomplete. That is actually the main objection. The list is a good start in itself, but under the current economic conditions it is unclear and incomplete. This applies to both employers and employees. If employers do not comply with this list, they may lose their reputation as a reliable transport company. These employers do indeed have something to lose. And it has to be clear to the employers that they do have to abide by and what they don't have to abide by. The same applies to the workers. Of course, there is also a social aspect in this list. There are several elements for workers in European transport policy that are unclear at the moment: elements such as remuneration, safety, and you name it. So we want a new list. And I fully understand what the Commissioner is saying – and whatever Mrs Meissner says – that we are now delaying, creating uncertainty. But if the Commissioner starts a new list at the beginning of next year, we will be able to approve it again before the summer recess and then everyone will know where he or she is at. Moreover, there is another element: unclear lists are extremely difficult for enforcers, the national inspections. We all know that one of the major problems in European law at the moment is: 'Can we maintain the things we agree on here?' Therefore, thanks for the start. The list is not complete, neither for employers nor for employees. Come up with a new list soon, so we can help the transport sector further.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul There are widespread problems in the transport industry in Europe. We see daily cases where the rules of the internal market are overridden by rogue operators in order to compete on unfair terms. When that happens, it is the drivers and the serious companies who suffer negatively. And we know that competition in the internal market must take place on an equal footing, that it must benefit both employers and workers and all Member States.  For it is when we fail to do just that that we create a breeding ground for populist and nationalist parties and movements that want nothing more than to find excuses to break up cooperation and back into the future. Unfortunately, in my country, the cheating of cabotage rules and other labour market legislation is too widespread. It is time for the European Commission to stop turning a blind eye to the problems experienced by people in the transport industry. If people and businesses feel that they do not benefit from being part of the internal market, but rather that it threatens one's pay and job security or even the chance of survival of one, then one needs to know that those who have the power to change are also prepared to do something.  If the answer instead is, 'no, we see no problems' and 'no, we are not going to do anything about it', then confidence is quickly eroded. Illegal cabotage services are a serious threat to the EU and the basic idea of free movement. The addition of these offences to the list of serious infringements is logical and necessary in order to show that we take the problems seriously. When drivers are used for work in slave-like conditions, this obviously entails a lower road safety, an increased risk of serious injury and death.  Should the EU choose to say 'no illegal cabotage and social dumping is not so serious', I can promise that many across Europe would be extremely disappointed, because this is exactly what many see as the biggest problems today. Come back with a better proposal.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, I also congratulate the new Commissioner. It is an entry, because Parliament rightly objects to what is now before the Commission. What is it really about? The bottom up is that a road transporter can lose his license if he commits a serious violation. As far as I am concerned, that list of serious infringements also includes tackling unfair competition and social dumping. Unfortunately, the Commission does not think so. But the systematic abuse of the Cabotage Regulation and the Posting of Goods Directive are ruining European road transport. So it is really important for Europe to address this. This may, for example, move towards a system in which we make a real link between the usual workplace of an employee and the right applicable to his employment contract. Of course we have to go for it. Mrs Bulc, it is crucial that you consider this. I have also learned something from this whole process, namely that we should do this kind of important thing not through a comitology procedure, but through the normal regular legislative procedure. It's far too important for that. So, Commissioner, we will not support you, but we assume that the broad-based call of this debate to tackle social dumping and unfair competition is crystal clear to you.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: Mr President, in the Netherlands we often say: 'Without transport, everything stands still'. Today we can really say: 'With EPP, with S&D and a number of other parties, the transport sector in Europe is at a standstill'. And that is a pity to see. In my opinion, is the European Commission's proposal perfect? My answer to that is no. It does not include all possible violations that transporters can commit and which would jeopardize their good reputation. However, this proposal does offer a very good starting point for tackling the rogue transporters. We very often draw up European rules here in this House and think that this will level the European playing field. But that level playing field very often only arises if the rules are actually effectively implemented throughout Europe, are enforced, sanctioned. The Commission's proposal is now in danger of being rejected. Effective implementation, enforcement and sanctioning of the rules in road transport is therefore not one step closer, but a step further away. This brings me to a final point, which is also very closely related to this. It concerns the introduction of the minimum wage in Germany on 1 January 2015. This brings with it a great deal of uncertainty for the European transport sector. International transport companies very much want that clarity and my question to the European Commission is that if hauliers actually comply with the rules, they would not be faced with all kinds of red tape.

name: João FERREIRA
text: The struggle of road, freight and passenger transport workers and their representative organisations to improve respect for their labour rights, working hours and rest periods is already a long struggle. A fight filled with various clashes and difficulties, created both by unscrupulous bosses and by a European legislative framework more interested in promoting sacrosanct free competition – and the inevitable monopolistic concentration that always comes to it – than in properly protecting and defending the health and safety of these workers.  The exploitative voracious that has also befell this sector also follows the steps taken in the implementation of the so-called internal market for road transport. Here too, the contradiction between the myrific promises that the internal market would deliver and the harsh reality faced by workers in their daily life is striking. We have been, we are and we will be by these workers' side. In the fight against the race to the bottom of rights and convergence in the progress of normal social and labour.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to welcome you to this circle for your first speech. As chairman of the Committee on Transport, I would like to stress that there is agreement between all the political groups that the issues of fair competition and social conditions must at last be given the appropriate importance. Our committee is therefore strongly in favour of ensuring that compliance with existing laws is finally enforced consistently on our roads!  The Commission has been lax in this respect in recent years and has failed to play its role as guardian of the Treaties. As the new Commissioner, you, Mrs Bulc, now have the opportunity to write a new chapter and to abandon ignorance of social dumping. A lorry driver who spends his weekly rest period of 45 or 66 hours only in the driver's cab is a major threat to road safety. It is also illegal. That is why this must be prevented. Illegal cabotage, bogus branches, letterbox companies, forgery of the ticket certificate – all this was present in the original draft. Both have been deleted. That is incomprehensible, and that is wrong. That is why we too want existing laws to be complied with. Commissioner, you can tell our committee behind you if you ensure compliance with the law, tackle black sheep in all modes of transport and ensure fair competition – and, above all, start revising them as soon as possible.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Unlike the vast majority of you in here, I've spent most of my working life in a truck cab. As recently as March this year, I parked my car after 30 years on the road. I have seen the problems that have arisen and I would say that the biggest problems they come from this House. When cabotage legislation was introduced, that's when the cheating really started.  Because what is happening today is that, unfortunately, many of the major freight forwarders in Europe – and we are talking German Schenker, German DHL, Danish DSV – are using this cabotage legislation to operate illegal domestic traffic. The third transport you have to take over a seven-day period, it is transported to, from my country seen Sweden, to neighbouring Denmark and from Denmark you drive to Sweden, and then the car is back.  We have over 2000 cars operating illegal domestic traffic in Sweden; it is proven by an investigation. It is not possible to say that this can be fixed at national level because it is under the umbrella of the European Union that this is allowed to happen. It is European legislation that makes it possible. We must act with vigour here. European legislation is breaking up all the serious haulage that exists, because there is no one who wants to pay what is needed for a transport, because it is the last line in a product and it should be as cheap as possible. This is at the expense of the drivers and they are being used as pure slaves.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for being here and for the clarifications you have given us in the foreword. The main point, which other Members have also made and which I share, concerns the centrality of transport in the future of the Union, both as regards the transport of goods and as regards the transport of persons. However, we have ventured on a very complex and in some ways dangerous path: that is, the Commission has decided to indicate in the delegated acts, strictly, which are the cases in which the carrier is in danger of losing his good repute and therefore risks losing his authorization to carry out his service. That is where I question what some of my fellow Members have also said. When do you decide to indicate the cases in which you risk losing your good repute? If the indication is exhaustive, the reasoning is not valid so if we have done something good, it is appropriate not to delete it and move forward. In fact, as long as they are identified by means of a general criteria rule, then one can accept the beginning of a journey. But when it comes to the mandatory indication, anything that is not included in the mandatory list, is granted. Or rather: everything that is not indicated, in this case, as serious – because that is the point – will not be such as to allow the suspension of the authorisation to the service. So, at this point, I take as an example the case that, in my country but also in others, it is considered absolutely the most serious, namely that of illegal cabotage: the fact that the mandatory indication provided for in the delegated act does not qualify illegal cabotage as such, also worries my country about the social consequences that this will have. Therefore, serious consequences on the business front but serious consequences also on the social dumping front. I would ask for special attention to be paid to this, and I agree with my party's suggestion that this list should be completely revised. Thank you very much for the work you are doing.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: Madam President, the Commissioner should consider this. People outside this Parliament might risk not understanding that what we are talking about here is far from being a technical issue. I think it is important to remember that thousands of people in Europe die each year as a result of lorry crashes, and so it affects both the drivers and the people on the roads. For example, in 2011 the European Transport Safety Council highlighted that 4 300 people died. Now you tell us, Commissioner, that what we are asking for is out of scope. That is absolutely not true. There is ample evidence that driver fatigue and abusive employment practices and exploitation, not taking safety seriously, and illegal cabotage more generally, lead to very real safety risks and will not enable us to meet our road safety targets apart from anything else. How can this possibly be out of scope? You also said there was an issue of legal certainty. Again I cannot see how that can be correct; it is not as if there is no law at the moment. However the main point that we are making to you, pretty much all of us here, is that this proposal has no added value. Please think again, and if nothing good comes back that is not our fault: it is your fault.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the issue of transport safety is crucial. And it is crucial because too many lives are lost a year on the roads because safety rules are not respected. There are unscrupulous drivers but mostly there are businesses that have trucks that really don't have tyres. Their tyres are worn out; are in bad shape. They're carmanioles trucks. Let me tell you that recently, on Egnatia Road, a truck with a driver from Romania and owned by a Romanian company crashed into 30 cars. We had three dead. We had 30 wounded. This is therefore a very serious matter, because they do not comply with the safety rules and do not have their businesses properly structured, and they have their cars purely to make a profit. This is the key element, as well as social dumping, which is also an important dimension, which the other Members have just given.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: Madam President, this debate perfectly illustrates almost everything wrong with the thinking of the European Union. Saying that 500 million people are a single market does not make them one. A single market based on freedom of movement can only work when there is something approaching a common standard of living. There is not. Poor income in Bulgaria and Romania does not even give a monthly wage which is as good as the UK’s minimum wage. This means that the lorry drivers of the UK simply cannot compete and earn a decent day’s living. We know there is widespread corruption with licences that can be bought on the Internet. This has led to some unqualified drivers on our roads.  Let me make a couple of points clear. I am not blaming the people of Eastern Europe; they just want to make a living. I am not opposing free trade; but the role of the markets is to increase prosperity, not to create a rush to the bottom. These problems are completely and utterly the result of pie-in-the-sky thinking by EU decision makers. It is the EU’s economic illiteracy which is to blame. When will they understand that the objective is prosperity? They talk about good repute of lorry drivers. It is not lorry drivers who are the problem. It is the unelected Brussels Commissioners and their bureaucratic staff who are dreaming up policies devoid of any understanding of how the real world works. The end result of this type of legislation punishes the hard-working lorry drivers of Great Britain.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The regulation, which is the subject of our discussion today, resolves the issue of infringements of the so-called good repute and its loss by road hauliers. In my view, the Commission has not fully defined all road safety offences and it is important to agree with those who raise those doubts. A delegated act should be full, transparent and lead to better compliance with the law, not allow for free interpretation and selective treatment. We have too many road accidents and related human tragedies to treat the subject superficially. I therefore support those who say that the list of infringements should be supplemented.  The discussion on the regulation has also opened up another area which is causing more and more controversy, which concerns cabotage and so-called social and social dumping. It should be stressed that cabotage is regulated by a separate Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council and that infringements in cabotage do not give rise to a loss of good repute by the carrier, as they have no direct link with road safety.  When we talk about social issues, we need to take several aspects into account. Firstly, we have one European Union, we have a common market, but we also have significant differences in the level of remuneration for the same work in the different countries of the European Union. Secondly, it must not be forgotten that workers and drivers from one EU or non-EU country are often employed under completely different conditions and far lower rates than those in the European Union country where they work. Thirdly, uncomfortable problems cannot be solved for a country or government at the expense of other countries. I agree that this is a very difficult and important subject, which is why I believe that there needs to be an expert and fact-based discussion on the extent of infringements in the international road haulage market and the development of common instruments to counteract the phenomenon of illegal cabotage.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: Commissioner, we all know that transport is one of the elements that give sway and effectiveness to the economic dimension of the European project. That is why we need a secure road infrastructure with uniform rules, and at the heart of the concerns must remain the citizen, to whom we owe it to ensure optimal working conditions and safety. This is the rule that all carriers must follow. The Commission must therefore develop transport legislation capable of regulating unfair practices, respecting competitive principles, combating illegal cabotage and supporting economically and socially staff working in this field. I demand that the rights of all employees be respected, and otherwise EU sanctions should be applied quickly and effectively to discourage any case in which carriers pay their employees less than required by law, employers use fictitious forms of employment, carriers do not pay employees social rights and insurance and employees' working times are not respected. If we are talking about safety on public roads in Europe, we must bear in mind that the main cause of accidents is the physical exhaustion of drivers, who are forced to live in the truck cab for weeks and are forced by employers to drive 9-10 hours a day without interruption. Given that international transport and transnational employment are widespread economic practices, we cannot afford to ignore the social character of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1071/2009. That is why, for the rights of these people and for the safety of all road users across Europe, we need legislation adopted with caution, which imposes uniform rules on all those working in the field of transport.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Here we comment on the issue of the good reputation of road hauliers of cargo and passengers. I would also like to point out to you another issue related to this topic – namely the level of competition protection in this industry and good generally accepted practices. Because there are provisions and practices in individual national laws that discriminate against small carriers at the expense of large carriers, those from one Member State at the expense of those from other Member States. Do you consider it normal, for example, to require french and Belgian legislation to make weekly rest compulsory in a hotel and not as it has been done in the cab of the truck? Isn't that discrimination against smaller transport companies than the rest of the Union?  And another – the issue of non-EU third-country carriers. Here I would like to draw attention to the carriers from Turkey – extremely undisciplined– and also to the legislation of Turkey, which does its utmost to prevent other carriers from the other Member States. They do not comply with Union rules for comprehensible reasons. This creates tension, including social. We can't turn a blind eye to this. Therefore, before we talk about good practices, we must solve the problems of unfair State aid and regulate equal treatment, end inequalities.

name: Andor DELI
text: Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner. Today's debate is linked to the draft decision by which Parliament is preparing to reject a revision of the Commission's list of road hauliers' infringements. We'll vote on that on Wednesday. It is very important to draw up a qualitative and fair list of infringements and it is essential to combat any illegal behaviour, so that the absence of a Community driving licence or driving attests cannot be tolerated. It is also necessary to take action against illegal cabotage, as it reflects badly on all carriers legally engaged in cabotage.  Nevertheless, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that the eradication of so-called social dumping cannot, and indeed is harmful, to start and proceed selectively in certain narrow sectoral policies. Rather, a comprehensive initiative would be needed to speed up the social catch-up of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, since the cause should be eliminated, not the symptoms treated. The enforcement and control of the national social legislation of the Member States cannot be taken over by the European Union by an act of delegated powers, as it may ultimately disrupt the unity of the road haulage market, making it more difficult to implement the principles of free movement of goods and the freedom to provide services.  The fact that the Council supported this Commission proposal raises further questions and points out that solutions may need to be sought elsewhere and differently. Thank you.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Mr. President, Madam Commissioner! I would like to say this as a by-means that I would also like to see a good cooperation with you, and I should start with one comment: I do not think you should make a mistake in your next five years that your predecessor made. He has pursued transport policy solely under the auspices of his ideological ideas that the big ones should become stronger and that the little ones should disappear in the end – also with the freight companies.  This regulation, which he has proposed here, reflects this idea: little regard for social legislation, reduction of penalties, restriction of penalties. These are all things that those who are small and honestly mean it cannot get around, because they cannot move their seats, cannot hire drivers from all over Europe. The little ones suffer from this, and the big ones benefit. In the end, this means that everyone has less except a few big ones who earn more and more. That is not what we want here, this kind of transport policy. That is why I believe that this will also be rejected and that you will have to come up with a new better proposal. I hope it will be better, and then you will also have the support of this House, which would be very reasonable. I just wanted to say that to you, and i would like to end with a few words, Commissioner: do not allow yourself to be fooled here by some of my fellow Members who, unfortunately, have disappeared with their fan club. They are already democratically legitimised to do things here.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Chairman! Dear Commissioner, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work. I didn't hear you speak, but I know your point of view. I missed a little bit. I am pleased that you are here for your first fire baptuation in this building, in this room. In fact, when we are discussing today the comitology regulation on the classification of serious infringements committed by road hauliers, we are talking about the internal market for road transport. And let us be frank, colleagues, it reminds me very much of the service directive debate here several years ago, in which the political views of employers and workers often coincided depending on the geographical aspect of the European Union. And so is today. We often say that there are no more cases in the delegated act you have submitted. But there is. There are fatigue requirements, there are technical requirements. The fact that there is probably no social dumping is not the availability of so-called illegal cabotage, although in 2009 we decided that this cabotage would be on the road transport market, etc. Here I would like to say a few words in English, knowing that I am in the minority and will be one of the few who will support your proposal, to say a few words at once in English, so that my colleagues perceive my idea well. We'll match it. We have rules here in this House for our local assistants. This is clearly social dumping. It is not admissible that local assistants from Bulgaria should be paid eleven times less than Danish local assistants! So what is this called? It is social dumping. We are pushing our local assistants into a lower quality of life; They are not sleeping very well, their beds are so bad, and they are not eating properly and so on – and they are giving advice to our MEPs! The only good thing is that we MEPs from eastern Europe are not creating a safety hazard for political decisions here. I am, of course, being sarcastic. But we have to think about it, about what we are talking about here sometimes.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mr President - welcome Commissioner, on my part too - ladies and gentlemen, considering all that my colleague, Markus Ferber, has just said on behalf of the European People's Party and which I fully share, I would like to add a few points which I think are also very important. We will not achieve our road safety objectives and we will not be able to improve the reputation of the sector without taking into account the social aspects. The human factor is central to our fight for safer roads. Many accidents are due to a lack of attention and reaction from drivers due, in particular, to poor working conditions. The Commission had a real chance, a real opportunity to address the weaknesses in the implementation of the Union's social and labour legislation, as well as the mandate to prevent social dumping, according to Article 6 of Regulation 1071 establishing common rules on the conditions to be met in order to practise the profession of road carrier. The Commission has failed to include illegal coasting transport in its list, which, given its harmful effects on drivers, must undoubtedly be equated with a serious source of offences. I therefore regret that the Commission did not take these problems into account in the development of the list, which remains very vague and has many shortcomings and, as a result, remains unfinished. That is why I have rejected the list proposed in the Committee on Transport and Tourism and I call on my colleagues to vote in favour of our resolution. Nevertheless, we need this list because of the improvements it allows in terms of legal certainty. Transportation companies must take responsibility and, if necessary, ensure that their honour is maintained. I therefore call on the Commission to take Parliament's arguments into account and I call on the Commission to propose, as soon as possible, a new list of serious offences.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Mr President, be welcome, Commissioner. The truth is, it's up to you to bull someone else's bull, and you start very hard. So I hope you can face dossiers set up by you later. And if this were not so serious, I would say that it seems that this Parliament wants to help Mr Juncker withdraw legislation which he wants to keep as a subsidiary. It's not my case; I am going to talk a lot, because the objective of this classification, drawn up by experts for two years, is to harmonise to give legal certainty to carriers crossing Europe from north to south and east to west, and which, because of the discretion of the Member States, do not know what sanctions they face in each country. Thus, there are countries that plan to incorporate and impose prison sentences for those carriers who decide to sleep in the truck's cabin – and not in a motel far from their truck – in uninsured car parks, as has been said recently, and there are other countries for which driving with excess alcohol is not yet a serious violation, with the consequent risk. I therefore find it serious that the non-adoption of this proposal will maintain this discretion and, therefore, the abuses that some authorities exercise against foreign carriers, which are almost always peripherals: those of the East, the West, the South or the North. So uncertainty and discrimination and unequal treatment of carriers will continue to be condemned, which is ultimately what always happens. And for those who with all legitimacy and good intention seek to resolve social dumping and other cabotage problems with this rule— which relates to road safety, to point out that these matters are not dealt with in this Regulation or in this classification, but in the social package that you promised us, which we demand and which we continue to expect.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Union. The classification of and only infringements of Union rules on road transport, which may lead to a withdrawal of the reliability of a haulier, is undoubtedly the responsibility of the European Commission. The objectives are to create a level playing field, to create legal certainty and to avoid serious road accidents involving fatal and serious injury. In order to make the list presented by the Commission a binding benchmark for assessing reliability, it is necessary, firstly, to remove any remaining ambiguities, secondly, to concentrate on genuinely serious infringements – that is, certain aspects could also be deleted – and, thirdly, missing aspects should be included in the list. For example, the existing problem of professional drivers living and sleeping in their lorries for months today, which goes directly with social dumping, must be resolved as quickly as possible. If I recommend today that I vote in favour of the motion for a resolution, which contains the rejection of the Commission's draft regulation, then I am not concerned with a show of strength with the Commission, nor is it about revising the rules on access to the profession of professional driver, nor about opening up cabotage. It is a clear, manageable, sensible, red tape-cutting list in the sense of the objective. We need such a list in order to deprive road hauliers that repeatedly and systematically violate a number of existing EU rules of authorisation without opening the door to arbitrariness on the basis of a patchwork of arbitrariness. However, this list must also save those who abide by the rules unnecessary effort. I see a good chance of adapting this list to the New Economic and Social Policy Strategy of the European Commission as soon as possible. Finally, I would like to say that even the best list is of no use if compliance with the existing rules is not monitored consistently, efficiently and non-discriminatoryly at Member State level.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr. President! As coordinator of the European Socialists in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I am very grateful that the Committee on Transport and The Commission, including my colleague Ismail Ertug, rejected this List of the Commission. I have been in close contact with lorry drivers, with trade unions, with small and medium-sized enterprises for many years, and what I am experiencing on European roads is a disaster for workers, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises. There are drivers who drive across Europe for EUR 300 a month and – as colleagues have said – sleep in the cabins, spend the day and night in the lorry, and that really borders on modern slavery.  This causes a great deal of anger among those affected and the companies that work legally, which also take the social security of their workers seriously, because they are not up to the pressure, the undercutting pressure. Increasing liberalisation is at the expense of workers, but also at the expense of companies that treat workers properly.  The logistics sector is also showing once again how freedom of competition has been placed above social rights in recent years – and that must change. Goods and goods are cross-border, and infringements must not end at borders, but must be carried out across borders, where exchanges must take place.  A list must include breaches of workers' rights and social rights. Injuries to driving and rest periods, letterbox companies, bogus self-employment, drivers who are now suspended at rest stops and waiting for days to see if they can get a follow-up order are just a few examples of what we are seeing in lorry traffic in Europe, and I would ask you, Mrs Bulc, take the interests of the people of Europe seriously and make a fresh start.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Mr President, the debate here has been very negative. It is understandable, of course, that the main focus here has been on problems, because we want to improve the Commission's proposal. It is a serious matter, a catalogue of serious infringements. However, I would like to remind all of us that the objective of free movement of people, goods and services within the European Union is a very important objective in itself. It is worth striving for this together. However, this requires us to have common rules that can also be enforced.  Concerns about road safety have been raised very strongly here. Road safety is exactly what we certainly get the most feedback from entrepreneurs, drivers and also from ordinary citizens who see and experience many dangerous situations in traffic when the rules are ignored or not properly enforced. As far as road safety is concerned, it is important that we have common provisions that are strictly enforced throughout Europe. It is also justified that some countries may have their own regulations. For example, I come from northern Europe myself, and in winter conditions in freezing conditions, it is justified that the countries of northern Europe demand, for example, stricter tyre requirements for trucks. It's about road safety. It is equally important to ensure that we do not accept tax avoidance and the shadow economy. We know that it is easily related to transport, the transport of goods. In fact, transport entrepreneurs themselves strongly support increased controls. According to a recent survey conducted in Finland, 90 per cent of hauliers considered annual control over the payment of taxes to be very good.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Mr President! For too many years we have witnessed worse and worse working conditions in the transport sector. Too many drivers work in conditions that we cannot be aware of and nothing has been done to reverse this trend.  Unfair competition, social dumping and illegal cabotage operations are also detrimental to road safety in Europe. European drivers across Europe are under pressure! You don't have to talk to a lot of drivers about that to get confirmation. The same applies to the many employers who, fortunately, behave properly, but they cannot compete under these conditions. Of course, I support the need to draw up and adopt a list of serious infringements in the road transport industry, but illegal cabotage, social dumping and the consequent risk of poorer road safety cannot and must not be ignored again. It has already happened far too many times, and so it has not worked! I hope that the signal will be taken seriously, because something has to happen now!

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Dear! Road transport is the cornerstone of freight transport within the European Union, responsible for more than 70% of all transport and generating nearly 2% of EU GDP. This shows that it is a kind of bloodstream of the single market, without it it would be difficult to talk about the free movement of goods. Despite the great importance for the European economy, numerous barriers to the functioning of companies in this sector remain. Numerous restrictions make it impossible to compete between companies and thus increase the cost of transporting goods. It is estimated that the existing legal situation has a consequence of losses amounting to almost EUR 50 million per year. It is therefore surprising that some governments are calling for further restrictions and the possibility for operators from other Member States to provide domestic transport. If we want to boost the European economy, to increase production and reindustrialise, then we must create the most favourable conditions for the transport of goods. No country will attract investors unless it allows the rapid transport of manufactured goods.  Today's new list of serious road transport regulations prepared by the European Commission must be carefully considered so as not to lead to the collapse of transport companies, and precise enough to prevent some Member States from overinterpreting it. The use of excessive controls for protectionist purposes will not only undermine the implementation of the internal road transport market and lead to a loss of its potential, but will also further create an antagonistic climate in the international provision of transport services.  We all want to improve the level of professional qualifications of carriers and thus to improve safety on EU roads. The common rules for the classification of serious infringements of Union rules, which may lead to a loss of good repute by the road transport operator, should therefore be very precise and constitute a reference for national control systems. At the same time, given the legal form by which the Commission has drawn up the new list, it should be noted that the Commission does not go beyond its remit. Thank you very much.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Commissioner, I would like to join a number of my pre-spokesmen. My position on the Commission's proposal will also be critical. There are at least three good reasons to insist that the Commission's proposal in this form be rejected. The first is fair competition. We must not allow those transport firms that force drivers to work in inhumane conditions that practice illegal cabotage, which circumvent the rules, to have an unfair advantage in the fierce competition that is in place in this sector. This is unacceptable. The second reason is the worsening problem of social dumping. After all, the reputation of carriers must also include decent conditions for the drivers they employ – dignified, not slave-like.  The third and at the same time the most serious reason, with which the previous two are closely linked, is the safety of drivers and all other road users throughout Europe. How else to motivate carriers to remove unacceptable practices mentioned many times during today's debate than by consistent enforcement of the rules that will affect the assessment of their reputation. For these reasons, I cannot support the Commission's proposal in this form.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal to classify serious offences was expected not only by the European Parliament, but also and above all by the transport sector in Europe. This list should enable road hauliers who systematically commit serious violations of EU rules to be effectively excluded; those who refuse to respect the rules must no longer have the right to operate with impunity within the European Union. I can only be disappointed by the project presented today. Disappointed by this proposed regulation, which is both incomplete, vague and inconsistent. As an example, let me mention some of its shortcomings: it does not sanction illegal cabotage and, as a result, tolerates social dumping in the transport sector, which endangers the employment of employees and the existence of many companies which, in turn, work properly. This classification does not effectively combat social fraud, which we know leads to unacceptable working and safety conditions and genuine distortions of competition. Nowhere does this classification mention weekly rest in the vehicle. These serious deficiencies can lead to serious accidents or worse: fatal accidents. We cannot accept endangering the lives of workers and road users! These shortcomings are all the more regrettable because the social partners, the representatives of both employees and employers, had agreed on a common contribution. Unfortunately, despite the commission's direction, it seems that the importance that should be given to the opinion of the social partners has not been given due consideration. Today, it seems to me to be really important that the Commission should look again at this classification, with the help of the social partners. I am convinced that tomorrow this will provide a tool to address the legitimate concerns of the sector and of all European citizens.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, social dumping and its corollary, unfair competition, are major social problems in Europe, which have only worsened with the crisis. The single market will not be able to function as long as inequalities between workers in different EU countries widen. The transport sector is far from being spared and, while the Commission could have proposed a delegated act in the direction of social progress, it missed the opportunity to properly sanction the violation of social standards in the field of road transport. A company that is now caught with its hand in the bag to practice illegal cabotage would, tomorrow, under the proposed legislation of the Commission, still be allowed to transport goods in the European Union. While it is essential that the honourability of road hauliers depends on their compliance with road safety rules, respect for social rules is equally necessary. Parliament, the only European institution elected by direct universal suffrage, has been able, since the Lisbon Treaty came into force, to prevent the implementation of a delegated act of the European Commission if it does not conform to its content. Members of the European Parliament should take up this essential democratic step, in order to absolutely reject this incondic legislation which goes against the general interest of our fellow citizens. The Group of Socialists and Democrats will not compromise with serious violations of European Union rules. That is why we call on all MEPs to vote against the list presented by the European Commission, which will have to return to our Assembly with a complete list as soon as possible.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, ó a bheith ag éisteacht leis an díospóireacht ón tús, tá sé soiléir domsa ar aon nós nach nglacfar leis na moltaí seo. Ní hé sin le rá nach bhfuil na Feisirí i bhfabhar feabhas a dhéanamh ar an ábhar seo. Táimid ag caint faoina chur siar ar feadh tamaillín mar a dúirt Wim van de Camp agus nílimid ag caint faoina chur ar ceal ar fad. Má thógann an Coimisiún an seans sin chun éisteacht leis na pointí atá luaite ag na Feisirí anseo anocht agus a thriall iad a chur san áireamh nuair a bheidh siad ag déanamh athbhreithniú ar na moltaí is féidir linn moltaí an-mhaith a bheith againn a sheasfaidh an fód agus a chabhróidh leis an lucht oibre agus lucht taistil chomh maith. Mar shampla, luadh go háirithe dumpáil shóisialta. Gan dabht ar bith is fadhb mhór é sin. Ní féidir linn cur suas leis agus caithfimid gach iarracht a dhéanamh deireadh a chur leis. Dúradh freisin go háirithe a mhéid a bhaineann leis an Iodáil agus faoi chabatáiste mídhleathach. Arís is fadhb é sin. Níl sé féaráilte do na hoibrithe agus ba chóir dúinn riail shimplí ach fhéaráilte a thabhairt isteach a dhéileálann leis an bhfadhb sin. Freisin tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeadh páirc imeartha leibhéalta againn do gach aon tír agus bʼfhéidir gur cheart dúinn féachaint ar cad tá ag tarlú ina lán tíortha. I mo thír féin, mar shampla, tá an roinn tar éis foirm foirm iarratais mheastóireachta a thabhairt isteach a dhéanann na gardaí ar na daoine atá ag lorg ceadúnas sular féidir leo gnó taistil a bhunú. Is dóigh liom gur fiú féachaint air sin agus bʼfhéidir iad a thabhairt isteach ar fud na hEorpa. Dá bhrí sin, ba chóir dúinn féachaint ar rialacha comónta a bheith againn agus ansin monatóireacht chomónta a bheith againn ina dhiaidh.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: Mr President, accidents caused by drivers of motor vehicles for the carriage of persons and goods, even when they are not frequent, have serious consequences, loss of life and severe trauma in people who remain alive.
