Road transport of persons and goods has greatly intensified in the European Union and as a result of the enlargement of the European Union, but also as a result of the increased free movement of products and people in the single market. That is why I believe that we need rules, clear clarifications at European Union level on situations where serious infringements of Union rules occur, which can result in a road transport operator losing its good reputation. What we want, however, is that these legislative efforts do not introduce new barriers to the development of road transport of persons and goods, introduce new additional costs and allow discriminatory treatment of road operators, depending on their country of residence. As you have seen in this debate, it seems that the Commission's proposals do not fully meet these requirements.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, road transport is extremely important across Europe. Commissioner, when you see the investment, you are probably looking at TEN-T funding and establishing the trans-European networks and transport corridors. This is a signal of just how important road transport is in terms of getting business done, taking advantage of the single European market, and ensuring that goods from outermost regions – like my own country of Ireland – can get to the markets they want to access. There have been many contributions here tonight which will show you that there is dissatisfaction with the proposal: it is vague and it is not specific. That is really what the Members in my own Group, and others I have heard here tonight, want from you.  Everybody wants to have greater harmonisation of standards. I think that is essential when we are talking about improving road safety: safety of passengers and of individuals. We want to improve the professional standing of transport and prevent unscrupulous firms from exploiting workers. We want to protect workers and their conditions. I think that everybody is united on that, but it is how we go about it that is the problem. I do not think there is too much of a distance between the Parliament here and you, Madam Commissioner. With a little more time spent on this, the views of the Members can certainly be addressed. With road safety, the human factor is very much part of it. You cannot eliminate that, but you can always try to prevent it and create situations whereby the human factor can be eliminated. Hopefully the success you have had in road safety, where you have been trying to get to a position where we share information across Member States as regards driving offences, can be repeated in this area. I would hope that the Commissioner will be able to come forward at a later stage, should this be rejected, with proposals which are more specific, and not vague such as those we have had today.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Like many of you, I travelled here to Strasbourg today across the European Union – I travelled 900 kilometres on our roads. I must say that we have seen that, through our funds, we have been very supportive of the construction and completion of the road network. But that can't be final for us. The fact that we support the construction of a road network in the European Union must only be one step. This must be followed, in particular, by road safety, which is often subject to great pressure due to enormous congestion of the road network and transport at all, whether private or provided by different service providers. There has been talk of social dumping. Yes, I, too, come from a country where people still earn significantly less and where employees who work in other companies elsewhere in the European Union have much worse conditions. These are the things that the Commission must also deal with.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I was very pleased when you successfully passed the hearing and were elected commissioner, because I really expect great cooperation with you. I also want your mandate to be marked by successes, especially when it comes to transport and road transport, because roads are definitely the lifeblood of the European economy and we can say that transport in road transport means the lifeblood of the European economy.  In this context, I am committed to comprehensive solutions where Member States will play their role, but also where the European Commission will significantly take over the management of security on the European continent when it comes to transport. I see this proposal as a step forward, but it probably won't be enough at this point. That is why I want to express my support in the faith that exactly what you will be doing will allow social dumping to disappear and traffic safety in Europe to be higher.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is one point that has not been dealt with this evening: it concerns Article 13 of the Treaty of Lisbon, which considers animals to be sentient beings. I call for the level of seriousness of the infringement to be increased if the level of animal transport is not adequate. This is, for example, when there are no protections in animal lifters or when transport without valid or certified documents is not delivered at the request of the police. I ask the Commission this.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: The proposal for this piece of legislation has a great deal of attention to be made here in this House. In my view, this is due to the fact that this Regulation is intended to regulate too many cases. I therefore propose that we focus consistently on two aspects. Firstly, it should defend hard those provisions that have a chance of improving transport safety, and secondly, when it comes to social issues, I think there is a different type of problem here. Compliance with existing rules should first be assessed very fairly. After all, the main problem today is not to create new rules, but to have a whole range of good solutions, but these solutions are repeatedly broken and neglected. I think that should start with that. Thank you.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: A lot has been said today. However, I would like to emphasise once again that the legislative act on road traffic offences is too loose and that the classification is not perfect. I support the resolution for two reasons: firstly, for security reasons. The fact is that the standards of vocational education for the driving profession in Europe are different, and this is also reflected in road behaviour. Secondly, it is about the future of the transport sector. The transport sector also needs a generational overhaul, as the average age of drivers is very high. Labour conditions are already difficult to demand, and social dumping is further reduced. We must therefore all ask ourselves together how, in this situation in the transport sector, we should all be able to recruit young staff, thus also reducing traffic accidents.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Commission must express a strong common position providing for a harmonised sanctions framework at Community level with regard to road traffic offences. The alternative is for each Member State to take individual initiatives, which can create differences in treatment from country to country. I therefore welcome the European Commission's efforts to draw up a list of serious road traffic offences which may lead to the loss of a reputation for the carrier, which is an essential requirement for owning a licence. However, I cannot but agree with the recent position of the European Parliament's Committee on Transport, which rejected the list presented by the European Commission. I believe that the European Commission is in fact obliged to propose more ambitious legislation in this regard, which is capable of protecting and enforcing the social rights of workers, combating social dumping and illegal cabotage, which must be absolutely included in the list. I also believe that the Commission must work on the harmonisation of costs at Community level, in order to prevent social dumping and to prevent the race to the bottom which ends up deteriorating both the occupation of the carrier and road safety.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I thank the honourable Members for their very important remarks on this important implementing measure. I listened to all of them very carefully, and I can assure you that they will all be analysed with respect. But please just allow me one clarification. Illegal cabotage is a serious infringement in the context of fair competition. Member States are obliged to penalise it and consider it when assessing good repute. However, it is not part of this classification, where seriousness of infringement is defined on the basis of risk of fatalities or serious injuries. Cabotage infringement is not linked to such a road-safety risk. I would also like to point out that, when assessing good repute, Member States should, however, also consider infringements against the national social rules, including those on pay and employment conditions. Nevertheless, we should all keep in mind that this is just one step. We already made clear that the agenda of this Commission includes addressing social dumping, which has no place in the European Union, but we will do so in consultation with social partners and with adequate tools at our disposal. But it is now time for you to decide whether you want the exchange of information to start now – allowing for better enforcement – or if you prefer to delay this further. But at the same time, please allow me to thank you for your very positive and very constructive comments and for offering to help with very good cooperation in the future, to make sure that transport stays safe and competitive and is a key driver of European future prosperity.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the implementation of The PRIMA (Partnership in Research and Innovation in the Mediterranean) initiative by Jerzy Buzek on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (O-000092/2014 - B8-0046/2014).

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Alternate author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you know, the Competitiveness Council adopted its conclusions on 5 December on a partnership for research and innovation in the Mediterranean area, the acronym for which is PRIMA. The process has been going on for some time and during the Cypriot and Greek Presidencies, which have promoted Council discussions on this issue, they have paved the way for the result achieved during the Italian Presidency. But the process is not yet complete, i.e. it must start operationally now. This point has been discussed on several occasions. I believe that we can now say, Commissioner, that there is broad political consensus on the need to establish structured long-term cooperation in the field of research and innovation in the Mediterranean area. The ITRE Parliamentary Committee, which I represent here, has put an oral question on prima's proposal under Article 185, because it considers that the subject matter of this initiative is of strategic importance for the current situation and, above all, for the development of the Mediterranean area and relations between the European Union and the Mediterranean. We all understand that, if this issue was important in 2012, when he was born in Barcelona, today it is even more important, precisely because there have been historical passages in these regions that will mark history, both in the context of an evolution and an involution, sometimes, of the countries of that area. We therefore need an effort on the part of the European Union, an effort to invest more, in these regions, in these countries and to do so precisely in the field of research and innovation, because we all know – we all say this for Europe but it applies equally to the other regions – that research and innovation are powerful levers of development but also of social, cultural, as well as economic and productive transformation. These are key factors, in short, of the capacity for growth and growth in a qualified and socially and environmentally positive direction, as far as development is concerned. This is how the idea of PRIMA was born, a partnership for research and innovation in the Mediterranean, an initiative under Article 185 that provides for structuring and implementation within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean, which has borne little fruit in recent years but which could find here a very useful and very important field of application. Now, the proposal has been developed with the identification of a shared scientific programme, joint programming, which is based on two axes, two pillars, i.e. inextricably linked: water resources and food systems, combined in the sense of safety, health and sustainability, issues that are also at the heart of many European policies, themes that also recall the next Expo in Milan , a world event held in Europe. The effects on the economic and productive structure are obvious to everyone. This programme, clearly defined its objective, aims to develop innovative solutions and promote their application, therefore research and innovations to be applied immediately in production systems, by end users, first and foremost farmers, to improve the efficiency and sustainability of food production and water resources. The programme has gathered an impressive critical mass of accessions: 14 countries which have also committed themselves to financial support for the programme and, in essence, to hosting any organizational locations, etc. I would say that, to date, it is estimated that the financial commitment made by the countries concerned is already in the order of EUR 200 million. Therefore, a great commitment to which Europe should contribute with an equally significant effort. I would say that this is an important programme, which could be the foundation stone of a new partnership between Europe and the Mediterranean. There is a lot of talk about this need for cooperation when we deal with major issues that are also linked to stability throughout the region and to many security prospects. We ask you, Commissioner, what you intend to do, what your programme is, what your proposals are, reminding you of a few points. We are asking for this initiative on the basis of Article 185 because we want Parliament to have a role, a voice, a joint decision on this programme. But I come back to a few points that I would like to refer to: a structured programme means structured research, which has meaning, coordination and logic, not fragmented and fragmented, which are an organic programme, capable of having future results. We call for clear and effective governance: effective in the implementation and also in the results, in the application, therefore a very clear technical-institutional responsibility and finally an adequate and medium-term financial commitment, because programmes of this kind do not they can start and stop but they have to give stability and security.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I am very pleased to be here with you today for what is my first intervention in the plenary as the Commissioner for Research, Science and Innovation. In my statement during my hearing, I committed to engaging in an open dialogue and to maintaining close contact with the Members of this House in order to ensure that the channels of communication are always open. In this context, I welcome the opportunity to have an exchange of views with you on the issue raised in your oral question. Firstly, I would like to stress that the Commission fully recognises the crucial importance of Euro-Mediterranean cooperation in research and innovation. Research and innovation are key elements for developing a stronger partnership for democracy and shared prosperity with our southern neighbours. Secondly, I would like to acknowledge all the work performed over the last two and half years by the EU Member States and their Southern Mediterranean partners, which led to the Council conclusion of 5 September, which I supported on behalf of the Commission. Particular thanks go to the Italian Presidency for its strong engagement, and, in particular, to Minister Giannini. Thirdly, Parliament too has also shown strong interests in Euro-Mediterranean cooperation, and I personally remember very well the three questions I received during my hearing: one from Ms Toia, one from Mr Blanco López and the other from Mr Borrelli – three members of the ITRE Committee – on the importance of the PRIMA initiative.  More recently, I had the opportunity to address the PRIMA topic at the structured dialogue I had in the ITRE Committee on 4 December. I am therefore perfectly aware that those co-legislators attach great importance to Euro-Mediterranean cooperation – as does the Commission. The chosen approach of focusing on food systems and water resources has the potential to contribute to addressing key challenges in the region. In particular, addressing the water/food nexus in relation to the specificities of the Mediterranean context may have added value for existing research and innovation activities and networks.  Now that I have addressed the content aspect, which in my view prevails over the rest, I cannot conclude without a word on the procedure, due to the specific reference to Article 185. Concerning your specific questions, I would first of all like to reassure you and confirm to you that once the Commission formally receives the joint programme proposal from the PRIMA group, it will carefully assess it and evaluate the best way forward – including the Article 185 option. Firstly, it goes without saying that any initiative will necessarily be built on – and avoid overlaps with – other ongoing initiatives in order to integrate efforts in a coherent way, to pool resources in a sustainable way and to take account of the long-term perspective. These should be the primary concerns. It is necessary to have a deep knowledge of the work that has been done before or is currently in progress in that field so that we can build on it and deliver on a winning partnership. This is now even more the case due to the new approach announced by President Juncker regarding better and smarter regulation, the aim of which is to reduce the administrative burden, especially for businesses, to ensure that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are respected, and to ensure that that EU legislation is actually fit for purpose and creates favourable conditions for economic development. Secondly, a mature, well-focused proposal from the Member States is a prerequisite for the Commission in order to assess the participation of the Union in the programme and determine the way forward. We will therefore check whether the proposal, firstly, has clear objectives and is relevant to the objectives of Horizon 2020 and the broader Union policies; secondly, this proposal should be proven to have EU added value in a critical mass; thirdly, there should be a sound financial commitment from the participating countries. All the points that I have just mentioned mean that the Commission takes the initiative seriously and will analyse the joint programme proposal in an in-depth manner. It should not be understood as a way to rule out any possibility, or, in this case, Article 185. Let me be clear with you: I want to proceed, but in a way that would be most effective in helping us to achieve our shared objective of strengthening Euro-Mediterranean cooperation. For this reason, it is premature at this stage to provide a timeline for the process to be undertaken before we have made an initial assessment of the joint programme and before we have determined whether the Commission will launch a legislative proposal as a result. Let me finish by saying that the Commission recognises that the recent developments in the Southern Neighbourhood are challenging. These make it even more important to deploy all instruments at our disposal for cooperation in research and innovation. These will always play a relevant diplomatic role.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you are now starting your adventure as a Commissioner, I am now starting the adventure as a Member of the European Parliament, so I wish you both a good job. The comments made by Mrs Toia on the agreement, on the programme, on the possibility of developing research and innovation through the PRIMA project in the Mediterranean basin, cannot but meet with my most convinced support and my request for effective and effective cooperation, including through the Commission's concrete presence in this programme. A presence which, as far as we are concerned, must obviously also be of an economic nature, and I refer entirely to the rigour and punctuality with which you referred just now to the way in which the Commission normally has to decide, how and how much to intervene in support of proposals such as this. Action is not taken for emotional reasons: action is taken for specific reasons and on the basis of a path that in the medium and long term provides genuine possibilities for development. Well, the case of the Mediterranean basin and the case of research and innovation are cases which, in my opinion, certainly meet these criteria, with particular reference to the particular arguments raised by Mr Beazley. Toia, in particular the subject of food and water. The issue of water is a central issue, it is an issue on which our people will have a great deal to work on in the future and it is a central point for concentrating development opportunities in those countries that need it. We, as Europeans, have developed entrepreneurial skills, development and research skills on these issues, and we cannot fail to transfer them. Nothing better from a cultural, educational and economic point of view than to rebuild and implement the strength of this basin, of the Mediterranean basin, through the theme of research and innovation. Therefore, I really ask you to support this path, respecting the criteria identified.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, following the momentum given by the Cypriot Presidency and the Greek Presidency, the Italian Presidency has also decided that the PRIMA initiative should be a priority within its Presidency. After two years of work, we can consider that this initiative is mature enough to make the leap towards a public-public partnership programme based on Article 185 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. And my group would like to stress the importance of strongly supporting this initiative, for a number of reasons. Firstly, because it recognizes the value of science as an instrument of dialogue, exchange and cooperation. Secondly, because it allows us to integrate efforts to find solutions to social challenges together such as those involved in this initiative: food systems and water resources, so important to the South. And thirdly, because investing together in research and innovation allows us to improve employment and living conditions in the Mediterranean and promote sustainable and inclusive growth in these regions. Commissioner, we must revalue the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership's agenda with our Mediterranean neighbours ready to participate and co-finance activities. But to do this, we want to stress that we need an instrument that provides institutional visibility and stability, as well as long-term confidence. And that instrument can only be Article 185 as a vehicle for making financial and technical commitments at this level. However, we also consider , as the Commission has considered , that these requirements, the requirements set by the Commission, are met by the participating Member States. In particular, clear and firm commitments from participants, a well-prepared agenda and a willingness to establish a well-organized implementation structure. Therefore, Commissioner, let us hope that these conclusions which we expect from the Commission will be in favour of the implementation and impetus needed for this initiative, but especially on the basis of Article 185 of the Treaty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Euro-Mediterranean cooperation can be mutually beneficial for countries on both sides of the Mediterranean, especially when it comes to research and innovation, which is the subject of PRIMA and which can contribute to economic growth, job creation and reduce migration to the European Union. PRIMA concerns food and water programmes. It's about health and the environment. However, in order to have a partnership for the Mediterranean, there should be no dangerous projects, such as the destruction of Syria's chemicals, which was carried out by the hydrolysis method on board the United States cape ray ship in August last year and which caused huge reactions among the inhabitants of Crete. What are the effects of hydrolysis on Mediterranean waters? We have no information on this matter. So these are serious issues, Commissioner, and we must also look at them from this point of view.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the growing difficulty in having water resources in the Mediterranean area puts the development of agriculture at risk. This is already the case in the island and southern regions. In addition, food security from land and marine resources is threatened by pollution, overexploitation and limited availability of fertile land. Demographic and urbanization trends also put pressure on natural resources, while changes in lifestyle and nutritional habits increasingly lead to eating disorders. The PRIMA initiative pursues innovative solutions to improve the efficiency and sustainability of food production, as well as water supply, avoiding food-related diseases. This ambitious objective responds to priority challenges for Mediterranean countries by promoting good social and individual health, access to food and water, and the well-being of people, while fostering sustainable socio-economic growth. In addition, the PRIMA initiative, inseparable from the great Mediterranean capital which is Barcelona, will be a valuable instrument in establishing long-term structured cooperation in the field of research and innovation in the European Union and the associated Mediterranean countries. There is already a political dialogue, as the initiative has involved partner countries from the outset, and several countries, on both sides of the Mediterranean, have already indicated what they want their financial contribution to be. This programme can play an important role in supporting European diplomacy and neighbourhood policy by reflecting the principles of reciprocity, solidarity and co-development, while promoting the stability of European borders. It is urgent that we answer a crucial question: do we believe or not that the Mediterranean area is more than just a geographical entity? If we think it goes further, we can't miss this opportunity.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, it is not enough simply to reaffirm our commitment to promoting Euro-Mediterranean cooperation in the field of research and innovation. It has been repeatedly said, during the Cypriot, Greek and now Italian Presidencys, that this cooperation is very important, as it can act as a bridge of cooperation between countries and provide solutions to common challenges faced by both the Member States of the European Union and our partners. We therefore expect, Commissioner, that the Commission will now proceed immediately with the financing of the research and innovation cooperative in the Mediterranean region. However, the aim should be to promote projects that focus on the interests and needs of society and peoples and not on the interests of multinationals. In the light of the specificities of each country, cooperation in research and innovation should aim to address important social challenges to enhance social well-being. Projects focusing, as has been mentioned and the objective, on food and water systems should therefore be promoted, but we believe that energy sources, such as renewable energy sources, should also be used – and when we talk about the Mediterranean, this is important. It should also be ensured that Euro-Mediterranean cooperation in the field of research and innovation is beneficial and efficient, based on the principles of mutual interest, common benefit and respect for human rights. Such cooperation is now more necessary than ever. To this end, the Commission must finance initiatives that will strengthen this cooperation, making a drastic contribution to achieving peaceful coexistence but at the same time promoting social development, giving impetus to the real economy in the midst of an economic crisis.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Euro-Mediterranean partnership aims to create an area of peace, stability and prosperity and to support dialogue between cultures of the region. In this context we support openly the PRIMA initiative which clearly points to the consolidation in a structured way of a partnership for research and innovation according to the principles of co-ownership, mutual interest and benefit sharing, but we insist that this programme should be tied to the specific needs and circumstances of the countries involved, in particular those of non-European Union countries. We are therefore waiting for a complete proposal from the Commission on how to implement the PRIMA initiative, and we would like in this regard to make three specific recommendations.  Firstly, PRIMA should relate not only to the countries in the Mediterranean area but to the Mediterranean itself. I think PRIMA should also address the challenges of the blue economy, ensuring the sustainability of its actions. The objective of PRIMA should be to focus research and innovation towards sustainably exploiting aquatic living resources while at the same time protecting biodiversity, ecosystem services and the resource base. Secondly, PRIMA must focus on food production systems that foster sustainable production of safe and healthy food in vibrant local economies. The common research and initiative priorities must be focused towards a low energy, low external input, low emission and low waste economy, and support the creation of vibrant local economies and assure food production supply chains.  Thirdly and finally, support for an Article 185 initiative with a dedicated implementing structure. We believe that the PRIMA initiative has today all the prerequisites to be established as a public-public partnership under Article 185 of the Treaty.  We then propose considering the possibility of establishing a new arm of the Union for the Mediterranean, which is probably the best way to achieve the partnership we need to launch this project with real possibilities for success.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that greater attention and cooperation between the Mediterranean countries is all the more necessary after decades of the Union's policy having concentrated very, very much, in the North-East. In the meantime, the countries of southern Europe have suffered greatly from both the entry into force of the single currency and austerity policies. We will therefore give full support to the partnership for research and innovation in the Mediterranean area, but clarifications are needed. A Mediterranean New Deal cannot but be accompanied by extreme rigour: and rigour does not mean the inhuman and ineffective rigour of austerity but rigour over the legitimate and appropriate use of European funds, in many Member States where corruption is rampant, and strict compliance with the regulations on the real participation of stakeholders and NGOs. We also believe it is essential that we also work on European legislation, which effectively combats the flourishing and spread of organised crime and corruption in the south as well as in northern Europe. Corruption is often fuelled by the non-misuse and misuse of European funds.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Mr President, I am convinced of the need to cooperate with the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean and I welcome the establishment of inter-state cooperation, in particular the interesting GALILEO project to which Morocco has been associated for almost ten years. Indeed, we aim to work together on major scientific, energy, ecological issues but also and, perhaps, especially on demographic issues. The European Union can probably play a facilitator role and that is why I do not see any problem with the European Union participating in this partnership for research and innovation. My country, France, has already committed to participate in the PRIMA initiative to the tune of 4 million euros per year. If this money is used well, it can be useful to the South Mediterranean populations, who regularly face severe food and access difficulties due to a great dual, climatic and political instability. Nevertheless, I draw your attention to the fact that these cooperations must be beneficial to all parties, which is implied by the very idea of a partnership. Among the counterparties we are entitled to demand from our partners is the necessary control of migratory flows. This question, you will agree, is not incidental. Thus, we Eurocritical - i.e. Eurorealists - do not throw the baby out with the bathwater. Our strong opposition to Euroglobalism does not prevent us from supporting the few projects that we believe are going in the right direction. Article 185 of the TFUE specifies that the European Union's participation in research and development programmes undertaken by several Member States must be done "in agreement with the Member States concerned". However, we remain vigilant because we believe that nation states must remain in control of their destiny, especially at a time when the European institutions too often seem to be working against the interests of the peoples of Europe.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank in advance for your words and your mood regarding the dialogue between the European Commission and the European Parliament, which I think is essential and which I share. Over the past ten years, a number of cooperation networks have been established, both at the State/State level and at the regional level, and significant results have been achieved in the construction of a Common Euro-Mediterranean research and innovation area. In April 2012, the Euro-Mediterranean Conference on Research and Innovation, organized by the Commission in Barcelona, called for a renewed partnership in research and innovation. In addition, and mentioned here, the Cypriot, Greek and Italian Presidencies of the Council supported this initiative because of the potential for significant improvement of the European Union's scientific cooperation with the southern Mediterranean States. It is almost impossible — and surely we share it — to separate R&D&I from higher education, as it is in this area that it is possible to make faster progress in collaboration between different States, using, for example, joint studies, joint master's degrees, mobility programmes, students, master's degrees, phDs, mixed university centres, among others. The PRIMA initiative is based on the principles of co-ownership, common interest and shared benefit, all of which are necessary to ensure the sustainable management of common resources and shared regional responsibility within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean. Concrete solutions must be provided to the common problems we face. It is good that the European Commission has recognised the potential of the partnership for research and innovation in the Mediterranean for all the States that make up it, as well as for the citizens of both sides of the Mediterranean. In order to achieve the success of this important partnership, it is important that the Commission has Article 185 of the Treaty on the table to provide high visibility, institutional stability and the long-term commitment of the participating countries. We believe that the Article 185 initiative is the most appropriate tool to address the overall challenges of the Mediterranean region in an integrated way, so it must be implemented — or should be implemented — as soon as possible. In any case, Commissioner, I share that the objective is important more than the process: it is more important what is how. But surely you share with me that it is also important that the search for how not to jeopardize what, does not jeopardize the objectives. For our part, we will be open to dialogue, as I said, but vigilant.
