name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, as a representative from Croatia, I welcome the informal involvement of our country in the partnership for research and innovation in the Mediterranean area and hope to formalize these relations soon. The Mediterranean has been the center of the known world for centuries, various cultures have exchanged goods and knowledge, resulting in huge stresses in all spheres of life for humanity as a whole.  Croatian spaces have always been part of the Mediterranean, and our scientists, artists and merchants have written pages of the history of this civilization. Croatia thus returns to its natural environment by joining the partnership. I hope, therefore, that Croatia's accession to PRIMA is really just a formality.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, the European project has on the shores of the Mediterranean the scars of all its abandonments: in schools and hospitals closed by order of the Troika, on the walls erected to isolate Europe from its victims, in the regions and states devastated by the neoliberal economy and opportunistic geostrategia. If it wishes to save itself, the European Union has an obligation to work with the Mediterranean states to close these wounds, creating a common agenda of development and external diplomacy. PRIMA is only a small initiative, but it is perhaps proof of Europe's willingness to embody the values of progress and collaboration with its Southern neighbours, the first stone towards creating a common scientific space in the Mediterranean. Needless to say, the problem, even limited, that this programme will start is of great importance: soil conservation, scarce water waste management, the development of sustainable agriculture and aquaculture are urgent challenges in this region. Environmentally and socially, but also economically. The Commission must certainly ensure that scientific cooperation does not meet the interests of large enterprises or contribute to the allocation of local resources, as is the case with export crops in the territories occupied by Morocco in Western Sahara.  Taking these precautions into account, we urge the Commission to finance this common research area which we know is essential for job creation and much-needed reconstruction of the Mediterranean area.

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I wish you every success in your work and assure you that you will certainly have genuine sharing and cooperation with us, because I believe that the area of research and innovation is the element of real growth and also with regard to what we have just defined as partnership, I believe that the time is indeed ripe for a legislative proposal and for genuinely offering institutional stability to this partnership. The path taken so far has created a solid consensus between the Member States and the partner states, which can be clearly seen from their financial commitment in support of the initiative. This certainly demonstrates the will to continue along a path that is considered to be valid in order to achieve the objectives of greater integration at scientific, managerial and financial level. The added value that would be derived from it is certainly out of the question, as we have all said. The Mediterranean states share the same problems and needs. The Union's action by strengthening synergies, between the multiannual framework programme and the action carried out throughout the partnership, can undoubtedly offer the instrument that will help to identify concrete solutions and common challenges.  The Mediterranean is currently experiencing very important problems, and it is also in this House that we continue to discuss how to solve, for example, the problem of immigration but also that of unemployment. I am convinced that this instrument will make a great contribution. I therefore ask you to proceed without delay in the application of Article 185 of the Treaty, which will contribute to the internal stability of the area through dialogue and dialogue in the field of research and innovation. I will end by saying that, as responsible for the EPP on youth policies, I am also convinced that research and innovation are the element in giving positivity and optimism to young people, who also see their future as personal and country improvement. I am also thinking of Ispra, the European research centre that resides in my province and which I invite you to visit, if it has not already done so, because it can be a springboard for a Union and a Mediterranean partnership, which we are already playing at home and which we can strengthen.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Demographic, socio-economic challenges, but also environmental issues, are very closely linked to this subject. They were already indicated in her speech by my colleague Patrizia Toia. The Mediterranean Research and Innovation Partnership has the potential to give research and innovation a bridge role among the participating countries, as well as to significantly strengthen the European Union's scientific diplomacy with its southern neighbours in the long term. I believe that the Research and Innovation Partnership can offer concrete solutions to the common challenges faced by the Member States of the European Union and the Mediterranean partner countries, and can also play an important role in reducing the current fragmentation and duplication between national and European programmes in the Mediterranean area. I therefore welcome, albeit only, the indicative financial commitments, which have been clearly declared by the Member States of the European Union, as well as by the Mediterranean partners. The R&I Partnership certainly represents a relevant and appropriate tool for promoting stable and long-term financial management and financial integration, as well as scientific integration, starting in the first half of 2017. The European Commission should no longer ignore the clearly stated long-term commitment of the participating countries to implement the proposed Partnership for Research and Innovation in the Mediterranean and come up with a legislative proposal for an initiative under Article 185 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, so that cooperation can start as soon as possible.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Mr President, a thank you and a special greeting to Commissioner Carlos Moedas.  I have had the opportunity to attend several meetings in recent months on the assessment of mediterranean fishing waters. All of them were unanimous in concluding that there is a lack of knowledge about the populations, biology and ecology of commercially exploited species. In my view, this is not due to the lack of research and innovation, but to the lack of coordination and transparency in international scientific cooperation with third countries. Mediterranean marine research institutes are excellent and research vessels are at the level of what we find in other major sea basins, but the functioning of international scientific management organisations such as the Barcelona Convention and the Commission for Mediterranean Science has shown that there are geographical-political barriers. In the Mediterranean context, we must focus on north-south cooperation based on dialogue and data transparency. The Partnership for Research and Innovation in the Mediterranean Region will fall far short if southern countries of this great basin are lacking. There are good examples of the application of Article 181 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, such as the BONUS project in the Baltic Sea. But the Baltic is very different from the Mediterranean, has a more diverse political geography. I take this opportunity to draw attention to enlargement, or the second suez canal. This process will result in increased maritime pollution, including many alien species. The expected impact goes far beyond the promoter country, having consequences throughout the Mediterranean, as it has, and has, the current Suez Canal.  For this reason, I call for a real environmental impact study that is holistic, comprehensive, profound, international and, more importantly, consequential. Blue Growth not only requires investments in the marine environment, it essentially requires intelligence in the precautionary approach to our common future. For this reason too, PRIMA is a priority.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, the Mediterranean has an exceptional importance for the European Union, but because of the fact that its territory occupies almost the entire northern mediterranean coast, as well as because of the potential that action and cooperation in this area can have for the growth and development of the European Union and mediterranean partners.  Policy-making for the Mediterranean began immediately after the creation of the European Union, but more concrete changes were lacking until the early 1990s and the famous Barcelona process. The past two decades have passed in the sign of numerous activities, but with no visible results. Conflicts in the southern Mediterranean are multiplying, the problem of migration remains not uniquely regulated, and countries involved in Euro-Mediterranean programmes have not prospered excessively, as the most commonly changed form, but not the content of policies.  Given the approach so far, we inevitably wonder whether the European Union's policy towards the Mediterranean targets democratisation or is more similar to polarisation policies and what are the possible options for getting out of the current situation? One of them is certainly the PRIMA programme already supported by countries on both sides of the Mediterranean and the Competitiveness Council. Even an adequate legal framework has been found in the form of Article 185 of the European Commission. treaty on the functioning of the European Union.  Mediterranean policies so far have been based on a centralized top-down approach from the north to the south coast of the Mediterranean. Perhaps the solution lies in changing the approach and focusing on citizens, scientists, research centers, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs who would really connect both coasts. This would also create an opportunity for action for non-European Mediterranean countries and develop the potential for their joint scientific cooperation to achieve what previous approaches and policies have failed to do. For all of the above, I join calls on the Commission to present a legislative proposal as soon as possible so that they can start implementing this truly laudable programme.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I've had the opportunity to personally see what the significance of this program may be. Namely, I had the opportunity to be part of the Union for the Mediterranean, namely the part concerning local and regional authorities. I have participated in countless meetings with fellow mayors and presidents of regions from Morocco, Algeria, Egypt, Tunisia. Their expectations are very high, Mr. Commissioner. Their expectations of the European Commission, of Europe in its entirety, are really very high from member states.  Your concentration is on research and innovation, but that's where I specifically want to say, really on harnessing the water resources and knowledge that Europe has with that, I think there needs to be something that we need to transfer quickly, to do really as soon as possible. Real growth, sustainable growth, economy, big cities in the southern Mediterranean, environmental problems, these are all topics where Europe can do a lot and I expect and support the Commission in these intentions.

name: József NAGY
text: Dear Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. I appreciate this great initiative because I am very aware of the importance of Euro-Mediterranean economic and strategic relations. These could be boosted by research and development on the basis of the Barcelona decision taken two years ago. As a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I consider this idea important because it could stabilise the economic and political situation in the region. We do not need to explain why this is important to us, because the domestic situation of our Mediterranean neighbours is crucial for the security situation in the region in order to ensure peace in the region.  Last but not least, curbing the illegal migration that is stifling the Mediterranean countries of the European Union is certainly a task that is impossible without the rise of the source countries. Finally, I feel that the European Union must act immediately, because if we do not pay attention, what has happened in most of Africa today can happen, that this region will also be resily assigned to interests in the Far East.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Mr President, now it is a partnership that is welcome, which is not completely unprecedented and, for our part, we believe that it must be valued, especially if it is based on those fundamental values which should always prevail in the European Union's relationship with its neighbours: co-responsibility, mutual interest and shared advantages. However, I fear that these figures may be nothing but dead-letter, and in this context I would like to address some questions. First, how was the choice of the water and food sectors to be preferred, and what is the involvement of our neighbors in this process?  I would also like to know what mechanisms are envisaged to ensure equal participation in these countries, thereby preventing projects from serving only one of the parties. I would also like to know what mechanisms are envisaged to ensure that the peoples of these countries are primarily the peoples of these countries who benefit from these projects, thereby avoiding the suction effect of the little scientific capacity in these countries, leaving them in the end even poorer. Finally, what guarantee do we have that this programme will not be intended to finance projects from countries such as Israel that are on the fringes of international law and which has benefited in the past from the framework programme which has helped, as we know, to develop its war arsenal, or to consolidate situations of occupation of nations, such as morocco's occupation of Western Sahara?

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, strengthening scientific and technological cooperation with the Mediterranean countries is a desirable direction. From the efficient use of resources, to the conservation of biodiversity, through energy issues, the challenges are undeniable and certainly better addressed together. We are well known to have our reservations about the Scientific Policy of the European Union – deep reservations and divergences. The partnership we are defending with these countries cannot, of course, fail to take them into account. The countries concerned, both those in the southern Mediterranean and the Member States concerned, should play a decisive role in designing this north-south cooperation framework and in defining their priorities, means and objectives. Issues such as the necessary strengthening of the framework programme's appropriations and its reorientation towards the prevalence of the public interest are obviously central issues of this partnership.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for all the support that you have shown tonight for this project. I took good note of the positions expressed here in this debate. Let me assure you that the Commission shares the view of Parliament in believing that tighter, renewed scientific cooperation with our southern partners is an asset for peace, stability, shared prosperity and growth in our region. Efforts to strengthen the partnership in the Mediterranean area through European and national programmes are to be pursued in synergy, coordination or alignment with other existing EU initiatives relevant to those areas. It remains of paramount importance to avoid duplication and to demonstrate convincing added value. The merits of any proposal will be carefully assessed on the basis of the above-mentioned criteria, and subsequently the best way forward will be evaluated.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this debate on the implementation of the research and innovation partnership in the Mediterranean Area (PRIMA). In 2008, France wanted to restart the Barcelona process with the "Union for the Mediterranean". Initiatives have followed, but much remains to be done. The PRIMA partnership is a concrete and positive project that can link the two coasts of the Mediterranean. It aims to ensure the coherence of research programmes in 11 EU Member States and eight Mediterranean states to better respond to the growing and shared challenges in the region. I say "shared" because the questions posed by the erosion of natural capital, the scarcity of water and climate change are having an increasing impact on the southern shore of the Mediterranean but also on the north shore. I therefore fully support this initiative and believe that it is essential that the strengthening of scientific and technological cooperation between the Mediterranean countries has the support of the European Union and the institutional and financial opportunities provided for by the Lisbon Treaty and the Horizon 2020 programme.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 150 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I would like to draw attention to an issue which, in my opinion, is very important. And it is a question that the National Front, with President Maria Le Pen, has accepted a €9 million loan from the First Czech-Russian Bank for its political activities. It is essentially indecisive whether this loan was granted by the Russian Central Bank or its Czech branch. In any case, however, the European Union should address whether or not the acceptance of loans to political parties from Member States from institutions from non-Member States of the European Union with which the European Union is also in an international dispute is in line with the principles of the European Union. In my opinion, there should not be a situation where a country like the Russian Federation actually pays a political party for its future activities. This is how China can proceed and so on. I think that the Union should pay due attention to this matter and I would like to call on it to do so.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Mr President, Romanian citizens have been the target of attacks by extremists in several European countries in recent months. Unfortunately, the lack of response to these messages leads to the emergence of abusive and restrictive government policies on the rights of all European citizens. Prime Minister David Cameron's recent proposals mean practically restricting the right to free movement of labour in the UK. In this context, I cannot fail to see that segregationist discourse is practiced today against Romanian citizens. This rhetoric produces real effects, which can even affect Romania's reach in the Schengen area. Mr Cameron, Romanians are also contributing to the prosperity of your country, and you are not allowed to restrict their rights. We will do everything in our control in the European Parliament to protect their rights. I respect the statements of Mr Juncker, who stressed that the freedom of movement of European workers is a fundamental principle of the European Union, but I would like concrete proposals for sanctions for any kind of anti-European behaviour. We cannot allow some Europeans to be considered second-tier citizens and I propose that a debate be held in the European Parliament to discuss the rights and obligations of all European citizens.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to draw the European Commission's attention to the very difficult situation of farmers - milk producers in my country, Poland. As a result of the Russian embargo, milk purchase prices are falling for another month in a row. Compared to the pre-embargo period, they have already fallen by around 20%. At the same time, farmers are being fined for exceeding production limits in the quota year 2013/2014. These penalties amounted to as much as EUR 46 million and were collected from payments to farmers for the current supply of milk in September, October and November, while prices for the raw material supplied plummeted. The European Commission has decided to support milk producers in the Baltic states and Finland with a so-called €28 million milk package due to a nearly 20% fall in milk purchase prices in these countries. Milk producers in Poland, on the other hand, do not include this package. Yet, as I have already mentioned, milk buying prices have also fallen by 20% in Poland, and I therefore expect the Commission to change its decision and the milk package will also cover milk producers in my country.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: In the previous mandate of the European Parliament, we were able to fight for a higher amount of funding for the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived. We should be pleased that the European Commission recently approved operational programmes under the Fund in 16 Member States worth over a billion and a half euros. Some of this is intended for direct food aid for the poorest, but for all of us it is more important to help these people get out of poverty. I therefore call on the European Commission to monitor the spending of the Fund and to monitor whether Member States focus not only on material aid but also on measures to participate in the labour market.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, Greece, due to the forthcoming elections, is under a vulgar attack by the european Union institutions themselves. I am addressing the raw blackmailers of European citizens from this step. Those who are cut off for democracy and overnight they are taking down elected governments by putting bank employees in their place. Those who in the European elections 'deceived' Europeans with the slogan 'your vote - our action' and today threaten them with the consequences of their vote. I am addressing Mr. Juncker, the host of the 'legitimate' tax years, who dares to tell the Greek people what to vote for, and I call on him to tell us the sums that companies have stolen from Greek citizens. I am addressing Mrs. Merkel, a preacher of austerity and morality, to give us the names of those who paid the German companies Siemens, Rheinmetall etc. in Greece to do their jobs. The Greek people receive neither suggestions nor threats. The course of your partners, who knelt him to make you liked, has been defined and their overthrow is now a given.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: A few words also on the agenda relating to flooding. It must be said that floods and droughts in recent years are quite a common occurrence, they are no longer an exception and we are no longer talking about centuries-old waters, but about annual floods. We have, of course, damaged the environment and continue to destroy it to such an extent that climate change is bringing more and more extreme weather events, such as drought, hail, ice, and this year's floods, which have hit the hard-hit Slovenia. Virtually destroyed entire areas in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia and Bulgaria. And it is time, of course, to change attitudes towards this and to start working preventively by correcting the consequences of mistakes. This means starting to invest in preventive activities: deepening riverbeds, cleaning rivers and all that reduces flood risk, and this is also an opportunity for new jobs.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: Mr President, HS2 is a flawed EU vanity project. It has no business case, and it will leave our country riddled with debt. It is destroying people’s lives and communities and ripping up graveyards and ancient woodlands. I do not want to see our precious environment ruined by this destructive rail line. The enormous impact it will have on many constituencies from construction work and subsequent blight will affect hundreds of acres of land. There are still unanswered questions on plans and costs, yet the project is still moving forward against any public wishes. It will only be supporting a minority at the cost of a majority. What passengers want is an affordable, reliable, comfortable and efficient rail network system that delivers from South to North and from East to West. We already have a network in place, but it is desperately in need of improvement, and some additional lines are needed in some areas. The victims of HS2 who have had their lives destroyed have not been awarded adequate compensation. This is a national disgrace.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr. President! At the EU summit on Thursday and Friday this week, the Heads of State or Government will decide on Mr Juncker's €315 billion investment package. Broad political fault lines are already opening up. Southern Europeans are demanding more fresh money, Italy and France want investment in infrastructure to be exempt from the deficit, and European Social Democrats agreed at the weekend that the package is too small and should also benefit workers more. An investment booster of 315 billion would certainly be good for Europe if it were a) real money, a real investment package, not a risk-taking package, and b) the European Fund for Strategic Investments would actually be a fund that clearly discloses yield expectations for retail investors in order to be able to mobilise private money. None of this is the case. But that is not the main reason why Europe is weakening. The main reason why this investment package is not an investment package is that there is no confidence in European financial markets and in monetary union. Companies no longer invest, they no longer take out loans because they no longer find the framework conditions. These framework conditions must be created. We must restore confidence in the financial markets and in monetary union.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – 250 million Europeans use the Internet every day, but there are still millions of European citizens who have never used the Internet before. I therefore consider the creation of a common digital market to be an opportunity that can not only make a significant contribution to improving employment, but also to improving the qualifications of Europeans. Building a digital market must focus on: 1. better access to the Internet, 2. expansion of e-commerce, 3. making electronic services available. The development of high-speed networks today has the same revolutionary impact as the development of electricity and transport networks a century ago. The Union should still ensure two objectives under the Digital Agenda: broadband coverage of 30 Mbit/s by 2020 and provision of 50 % of households by broadband over 100 Mbit/s by 2020. The digital economy grows by up to 12% every year and grows seven times faster than other economic sectors. For these reasons, I really consider the construction of the Digital Single Market to be a key priority in our common European market.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: Mr President, following LuxLeaks I and II, the people of Europe are looking to the EU to take action against tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. So the Socialists and Democrats are calling for three things: first, country-by-country reporting of profit; secondly, a Europe-wide approach to tackling tax havens; and thirdly, the blacklisting of companies who engage in tax fraud and the financial advisors who help them to do it. But we also need commitment from the rest of the EU: from the Commission and the Council. Tomorrow the Commission must indicate that plugging the tax gap will be at the heart of its priorities, and Member States within the Council must listen to the anger of their citizens at the end of this week and work together to overcome national differences and agree on strong joint measures. Tackling tax fiddling could release one trillion euros across Europe – money we can ill afford to lose. Let us seize this opportunity to stop tax fiddling and back the citizens of Europe and the SMEs who pay their taxes, not those transnational companies who do not.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Last week, a demonstration was held outside the European Parliament against the barbaric practice of killing homeless dogs in Romania. People of good will cannot accept that in a Member State of the European Union, in the 21st century, there is a brutal massacre of homeless animals. It is also a harm done to people who are helpless in the face of such cruelty. Mahatma Gandhi once said that the level of civilization and its moral development can be judged after it treats its animals. I respect people of good will in Romania and call on the Romanian authorities to put an end to this brutal practice because it is unsealed by European standards. I hope that President-elect Iohannis will show sensitivity and activity in this matter. Such practices are not really worthy of European standards in the 21st century. I ask the President to be active in this matter.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, before the end of this year, the Governor of the Irish Central Bank will sell a sovereign bond worth EUR 500 million, and then he will immediately destroy that money. I do not know if he will press a button or light a flame, but EUR 500 million will vanish. The Irish people will immediately start to pay interest on the disappeared EUR 500 million and in 24 years’ time will still have to repay the EUR 500 million to the bondholders. But this is not a once-off. For the next five years, we destroy EUR 500 million per year; for the next five years after that, we destroy EUR 1 billion per year; and for the next eight years, we destroy EUR 2 billion per year. We pay the interest and the principal to the tune of approximately EUR 80 billion to bail out a failed, insolvent bank. And why? At the time, we did it to prevent contagion in the EU banking system. They were desperate times, and desperate measures were called for. But those times have passed. We in Ireland are drowning in debt, with our debt-to-GNP ratio at approximately 150%. This illegal, odious bank debt must be dealt with and lifted from the shoulders of 4.5 million Irish citizens.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, it has been five years since the so-called eurozone crisis eptifies. A crisis that is still endless in sight, which confirms all that has been warned by those who, like us, have fought from the outset against economic and monetary union and the single currency, warning of the devastating consequences it would have and what life has confirmed.  Economic dependence and political subordination: these are the consequences of a decade and a half of euro. This is a path without a future, which the people will defeat by the fight. There is a need for serious discussion on the obvious advantages of the dissolution of economic and monetary union and the extinction of the Stability Pact – instruments that must be replaced by intergovernmental agreements between states that, freely and sovereignly, express a desire to continue on the path of economic and monetary integration. A solution that should provide for a programme of support for countries whose stay in the euro has proved unsustainable, in addition to due compensation for the damage caused, in the context of a negotiated exit from the single currency and the essential recovery of monetary sovereignty.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the mafia capitale investigation is laying bare the shameful link between organised crime, corruption and politics, which has managed power, labour and public procurement and which had as its operational centre, Rome, the capital of Italy. Unfortunately, it confirms what we have been denouncing for a long time: a criminal system that blackmails the healthy part of our society and involves, directly or indirectly, public and political administrators. We have long denounced the intrusions of organised crime into the management of immigrant reception centres, a truth that is timely emerging from the investigation.  What is happening in Italy should not be regarded as a local fact. Denying that there is a risk of a refluence of the mafia phenomenon in the rest of Europe is not only false, but would be the biggest gift that mafias and criminal associations could receive. Mafias and criminal associations that use secrecy and silence to grow and enrich themselves. As theology teaches, the supreme cunning of the devil is to make people believe that it does not exist.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a country in the European Union where 60 members – including Parliamentarians – have been in prison for almost two years. This country is Greece and the movement is called Golden Dawn. This is a glaring case of violation of political rights and also of electoral rights, given that elections are being held, all the more serious because they are at the historic heart of democracy. This banking technocracy, which commands Greece and which imposes solutions which the Greek people obviously do not agree with, represses a movement which is annoying to these globalist powers.  In my opinion, the President of the European Parliament must intervene to verify this situation and the validity of this judicial repression, which is a vulnus to the political rights of a significant number of Greek citizens. Solidarity, therefore, as always, must be due to the principles of freedom for those who are in prison for political reasons, and this, Mr President, you who come from a country that has suffered so much from dictatorship and has fought for its freedom, I believe that you understand it better than anyone else.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, as we all know, SMEs – and we constantly hear it – are the backbone of our society, and they will be essential for economic recovery across Europe. SMEs, whether they are employing five, ten, twenty or even fifty individuals, are started by an entrepreneur in general. It is a term we have come to use frequently, but it is a person who has the confidence, the ability and the brains to start a new business: somebody who has ambition and is willing to take risks. I do not think we are doing enough for young people to encourage them to become entrepreneurs, to give them the confidence to know that they too can start a business. We need to invest in our education system; we need to ensure that young people’s minds are open to the fact that they can be entrepreneurs and that they can have the ability to start their own business, even if it is only one or two employees that they may have. We also need to include suitable modules in our third-level sectors and in our colleges and universities to get young people thinking that they too have the possibilities to become entrepreneurs or business starters and employ people as well as themselves in developing our future economies.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: Mr President, I too rise to speak on the issue of LuxLeaks, like my colleague Ms Dodds, and how we should respond to it as a Parliament.  I think it would be wrong if we were to focus exclusively on Luxembourg. Luxembourg may well be the worst case but it is far from being the only one. We must focus on the wider issue of how it is that we have created, in Europe, a system which gives effectively an incentive to every Member State to become its neighbour’s tax haven, and that makes it so easy for multinational companies to evade taxes by shifting profits from one country to another.  The total amount lost to national exchequers by tax evasion and tax avoidance is greater than all the public deficits of national governments in Europe added together. That is the issue we must address – the systemic changes that are needed to put an end to that situation.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, those who have travelled to Cyprus by plane – there is no other way! – should know that Cyprus is a very difficult destination, because it is a remote island state and does not have good transport with Europe. We believe that Cyprus Airways should be rescued and, with its registered rescue program, we believe that the company can become profitable by 2017. Of course there have been phenomena of mismanagement, maladministration, but there have also been external factors, such as the economic crisis, which has affected both Cyprus Airways and Cyprus much more, and Cyprus cannot afford any more unemployed people at the moment. Moreover, Turkey's harsh embargo against Cyprus and the illegal airports operated by Turkey in Cyprus are a major problem for Cyprus Airways. The Commission has recognised this and has accepted that the Republic of Cyprus should give an amount in compensation each year to Cyprus Airways. But we don't think that's fair. It must be cut off from Turkey's pre-accession aid, so that it too can understand its erratic policy.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Tomorrow, the European Commission will present its agenda – the intentions and the perspective for the development of the Union. We also heard Mr Juncker's ambitious ideas for regaining investment, getting on the european economy's feet through the active involvement of the public and private sectors. In two days, the Council will say its word. Success is at stake in common and coordinated actions. At the same time, governments and individual politicians in Europe are trying to bluff, block the outcome of the crisis. Anti-immigrant politics in Britain, innuendo against eastern European countries, extreme speeches by French politicians against Bulgaria and Romania's membership in Schengen, xenophobic sentiment shifting European rules and creating new dividing lines and mistrust. Migration has become an election theme and argument for political struggles, a dangerous flirtation with citizens and a play on people's fears about jobs and social guarantees.  No political argument, no political purpose can justify such a policy. It is in the hands of the new Commission to tackle these dangerous trends and to protect the right to free movement of European citizens, the right to their work.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I will make my next comment in Italian sign language, showing my solidarity with my fellow Italian desicicices. Today in the European Parliament, I represent my fellow Italian desices. On November 20, 2014, 6,000 deer citizens protested in downtown Rome for the recognition of Italian sign language. Three countries in the European Union, Italy, Luxembourg and Malta, are sitting on the shame bench, as only those countries have not yet adopted sign language. On behalf of the Italian desiquit community of 60,000 people, I call on the Government of Italy to present the Italian Sign Language Act as soon as possible. Thank you very much.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: Mr President, the new Commission translates into a new approach to the problems of Roma communities across the EU. With the new Commission in office starting on 1 November, expectations of the credit allocated to the new European Cabinet increased. Among many other priorities, ‘changing the situation of the Roma’ – or ‘the European Roma minority’ as I like to call it – should be on the Commissioners’ agenda and also on the Member Statesʼ political agenda.  As a newly elected member of this Parliament, but mostly as a Romanian Roma, I am drawing the Commissionʼs attention to the following:  Structured, institutional dialogue between Member States, the Commission, Parliament and Roma organisations has to become an implicit, structured and valued working approach. The cabinets of the Vice-President and the relevant Commissioners need to have capable and experienced Roma experts to supply the necessary hands-on experience that the previous Commission did not have at the level which is needed. Together with the major European Roma organisations, the Commission must put in place an efficient monitoring mechanism that can show the progress that is going to be made by 2020, and that includes what we know has not been done by 2014.

name: József NAGY
text: Thank you for the floor. Unfortunately, I have to report that in my country, Slovakia, state aid for minority cultures has been radically and unjustifiably reduced in the last two years. Not only is the amount uncertain year after year, but most recently the government has a great deal of self-doubt about the distribution of money, and often ignores proven projects and ignores the proportions among individual minorities.  In many European countries, the way and amount of support for minority cultures is guaranteed by law. For example, it is defined as a fixed percentage of the respective state budget or national gross domestic product. The allocation of funds is left to the stakeholders themselves. This could be the solution throughout the European Union, because it would greatly improve the relationship between the majority and the minority, and minority NGOs and cultural institutions would not be subject to financial blackmail and could not be easily used as a political tool. I think that it is time to make an EU recommendation for Member States to settle this issue in this best practice. Thank you for listening.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been talking a lot about security of energy supply in Europe. However, I think it is an incomplete debate if we do not put a face on it, if we are not talking about energy poverty, of one of the greatest and most important inequalities of the 21st century. It is not enough for energy to reach Europe if more than 50 million European citizens cannot afford it, even to meet their most basic needs. We're talking about millions of pensioners, households with all their unemployment members, or workers with precarious jobs. So far, however, national policies have not been able to provide an adequate response. Even in countries like mine, there are, to this day, 200,000 fewer beneficiaries of the social bond. I therefore consider it a social priority to establish a European strategy that provides a common framework for all Member States to eradicate this new form of inequality in the 21st century.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Thank you, Mr. President. In Romania, the process of returning goods confiscated by the Communist regime has not only stalled, but also reversed. Recently, a final decision was taken to annul the restoration of a school building that had previously been returned to the property of the Reformed Church, i.e. effectively renationalisation. The case is also sensitive because the court may have acted on its own interpretation of the law. Romania undertook full restitution when it joined the EU, and the relevant laws were in place, but the interpretation of the law of the courts can reverse the whole process.  The decision is also outrageous because, as part of the proceedings, officials who performed their duties were found guilty, and people who implemented the law in good faith were convicted in not one but thousands of return requests. The decision raises serious doubts as to whether Romania meets the rule of law criterion, which was one of the conditions for EU accession. Thank you.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, one of the main challenges facing the European continent is precisely the demographic crisis. The depopulation and aging of multiple regions of the European Union is simply alarming. This demographic crisis affects the continent's own sustainability, its economic vitality and the survival of our social model and our model of territorial cohesion. It is usually accompanied by an increase in levels of unemployment and poverty, which defies the very foundations of cohesion. Article 174 of the Treaty sets out as the objective of cohesion policy to reduce differences between regions, with particular attention to those with serious geographical or demographic disadvantages. It is urgent that the Commission act, to develop a strategic plan for demographic momentum with the participation of Member States, with the participation of the regions.

name: Andor DELI
text: Thank you, Mr. President. An important foreign policy announcement in recent weeks was the statement made by Russian President Vladimir Putin, which has since been reconfirmed, that the South Stream project had been halted and that a new line of gas pipeline would be added to Turkey in a different direction.  Needless to say, there was a great deal of dust in the EU, but it was particularly sensitive to candidate Serbia. All the more so since the Russian Ambassador to Belgrade, taking advantage of the situation, has degraded the EU and named him as solely responsible for halting the project, inflaming serious domestic political tensions in the country. I would consider it important if the Vice-President responsible for the Energy Union, Mr Šefčovič, started strong and as soon as possible consultations on this issue with the candidate Serbia, as he did with the other EU countries concerned. The Serbian Government has already underlined its enduring commitment to the EU, and I think it is necessary for this country with a high energy dependency to feel the EU's support for this very difficult matter, helping to preserve the stability of Serbian domestic policy. Thank you.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, the National Union for the Progress of Romania is a centre-left construction which has as its main objective the introduction in Romania of modern progressive governance and ensuring the political, economic and social stability of the country. Seriousness, fairness and respect for the given word have become a real calling card for UNPR, a fact recognized by all political leaders as well as by Romanian citizens. The UNPR is based in its work on two main pillars: the national interest and social dialogue. Society Romanian has transformed profoundly over the last 25 years, but the younger generations of Romania are not well represented politically, and the assisted generations are in a permanent situation of social insecurity. They need a strong, pragmatic and progressive political voice to represent them - that of unpr. THE UNPR puts the national interest at the heart of political life. Only the promotion of the national interest, both in bilateral relations and within European, Euro-Atlantic and international organisations can and must be the most important common denominator of the parties and the only lasting binder of Romanian society. Romanians need unity, not only around common interests, but especially around the aspirations that have marked our history, evolution and define us as a people. But above all, the country needs leaders capable of consensus, cooperation, construction and progress. As the governments of which it has been a member have always supported to the end, UNPR respects its commitments and its word and, in line with the expectations of its own supporters, expresses its support for the continuation of Romania's current governance. UNPR's priority objectives for the coming period include: introducing the solidarity tax on big fortunes, increasing the acceleration of the absorption of European funds and increasing Romania's role and influence within the European Union and NATO.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the discussion on the agenda item.
